�% �#+�"�0$/ Chief Information Officer, age 61���, ��K �� ��(�E �������������)447��������� ��� ������� � � ��� � � �.��� �� �� � �� � � ��� �� � �� ���� � .(� ���� �� �������� �(� ����� � � � � � E ����.���������)4478����3������� �� �� � -,�'� ����-���������� 2���������*���� �2��+����� ������ � � � ���� �����8� �� � ���� ��.� �� �� ��������<��.� ��� ���� ��� �� ��� �� � �� ���� � .(� ���� � ����� ��� 2���� 8����� �+����� ������ ����������� �� �� � �������� �� ���� � ������ ��=&776� �&777@8� ���������� �� �� � �������� �� ���� ������ ��� ��=&7A6� �&776@���, ��K �� ��(��� ������-����� � �� ����������. ����������� ������.���� ��.�����,�� � � ������������. ����������� ������.���� ��.�%����� �� �(� ����� �� ���$��2� �� (� ��B��� ����L,���� ���

��'��#� ��� +�/ Chief Administrative Officer for Physician Practices and Chief Executive Officer, PCHA, age 37. �,���#������E �������������)4&:����+����� ������ � �������� (��� 2����� ������������������������ � �2�������� �� ���(�������� �� ���������������*���� �2�������� � ������� ����� ���)4&1���,���#������������������ ������� ��� ������� (�� �&/�(�� ��3� ����� ������� ��������� �� �� � � ��� � � � �� ��� � ���� ���� ��� ��������� �� �.�3� �� � � �.��� ����� E�� �����.���� �� �� � � � E ����.� ����8� ,��� #������ �� 2��� ��� 2� � ��� ����� ����� ���� � � ���� �� ����� �� ,������� ' ��8� ��������.� ��� ����� �� � ,������� ' ��� ������� � � � � � �� "��3 �� �� (� ���� ���� ,� � � � �� � ��� ��� �������� ������������� ��� ������� ��� � �� � � �������� � �.�����2�� ���� � �� ��� ������,��� #������ �� ���� ��-����� � ���������� ��. ��� �������������� �� ���� ��,�� � � ������������� �� ��. ��� � �� ���$��2� �� (� ��! ���� ����8��������������

�&�!�"$ ���%(#��/ -�-/ Vice President of Medical Affairs, age 65�� �# �� ����� .� E ����� �������� ���#�2��� �������� ������� ���"����� � .(����&7718�������������� ��� �������)44A�����3��� ��� �� ���+����� ������ � ��,������������ �����)4&&���# ������� .������� ���� ���� � ������� �������� #� �� � ������� ���"����� � .(�� � ���� ��� ����� �� ��,��������� �� � � � E ����.�����8�# �� ����� .�3���#� �� � ������� ���"����� � .(�����"������� � � �8������ ������ ��� ��� ��� ��.�� � �� (� =&7A)� �&771@8���������� �� ����������� ���� ������ ��������,�������� =&7A)� �&7A6@����� ��� ��� ����E��� �� ���� ������ ��������,�������8�$��2� �� (� ������� ���8� 2����=&7A6� �&771@��� # ������� .��� ������-����� � ������������. �������# � � ��,����������. ���� ��$���������� � ���� ����� �� � %� � ������� �������(� �����.�� ������ ������ ��� ���� ����.������

5�'�� �*��/ -�-/ �&-�- Surgeon-in-Chief, age 54�� �# ��#���� ��� �� ����� ��� �� .� �� ���� �� ��.���� �� � ��� E ����� ����� ��� �� �� � )4&6� ��� �� .� �%��%������ ���� ������ �� ��� #�2��� �� �� ����� ��� �� .� (8� #��� ��� � �� �� .� (8� � � ��� � ��� �� ��� �� �� ,��������� � # �� #���� 3��� � �2� ���(������� ������� ����� .� (�� �,� �������� ������ ��� ���� � ���$��2� �� (� ������� ���8�� �� ��.����� =>$���?@�� � # �� #���� �� ���� ���� -����� � �� �������� ��. ��� � �� ����� ���� �� � � �� �� ����� � .(� ���� . ���� ��� � �� �� 2� �� ,������� ��� �� ��� &77)� 3� �� �� � �� �� �� � ���#�� ��� �� ��.���� ��.�� ��,��������� �� �� � � �� ������� � .(�� ��� � �� ���� ��.������� .��������� 3����� �����.� � � $���� ���� �� ����� ��� �� .����� ���� 3����� � � ������� $��2� �� (8� ��� ������� �� ����� (� ����� �� �$�������)44&��

Physician Practices and founding Chief Executive Officer of PCHA in 2011 and was appointed Chief Strategy Officer in 2015. In April 2017, Ms. Roberts transitioned her roles as Chief Administrative Officer for Physician Practices and Chief Executive Officer of PCHA to Cameron D’Alpe. Prior to joining LPCH, Ms. Roberts spent 13 years with the Santa Clara Valley Health and Hospital System, first as Chief Financial Officer and then Chief Executive Officer. Her prior senior management positions include: Associate Director, Hospital and Clinics and Chief Financial Officer for the University of California, San Diego Medical Center, Assistant Director of Finance, University of California, San Diego Medical Center, and Assistant Administrator, Director of Planning and Marketing, Tri-City Medical Center in Oceanside, California. Ms. Roberts earned a Bachelor of Sciences degree in Biological Sciences from the University of California, Irvine, and a Masters in Healthcare Administration from Duke University. Ed Kopetsky, Chief Information Officer, age 61. Mr. Kopetsky joined LPCH in 2009. He is responsible for the strategic direction for information technology and biomedical systems. Prior to joining LPCH in 2009, he was a Partner at IBM Global Business Services and Executive Vice President at Healthlink, a consulting firm specializing in healthcare information technology and process improvement, Senior Vice President and Chief Information Officer at Centura Health (1996 to 1999), and Chief Information Officer at Sharp Healthcare (1986 to 1996). Mr. Kopetsky earned a Bachelor of Science degree in industrial engineering and Master of Science degree in industrial engineering - health systems from the University of Wisconsin—Madison. Cameron D’Alpe, Chief Administrative Officer for Physician Practices and Chief Executive Officer, PCHA, age 37. Ms. D’ Alpe joined LPCH in 2013 as Vice President of Ambulatory Services and became Chief Administrative Officer for Physician Practices and Chief Executive Officer of PCHA in April 2017. Ms. D’Alpe has been in the healthcare industry for 15 years with a focus in the field of operations for outpatient and inpatient clinics along with strategic and project management. Prior to joining LPCH, Ms. D’Alpe served in various leadership roles for The Permanente Medical Group, including as Assistant Medical Group Administrator at its Redwood City and San Mateo locations responsible for clinic and hospital department operations and strategic development opportunities. Ms. D’Alpe earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Public Health and a Master of Public Health degree from the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. Christy Sandborg, M.D., Vice President of Medical Affairs, age 65. Dr. Sandborg joined LPCH as the Division Chief of Pediatric Rheumatology in 1997, became Chief of Staff in 2008 and was appointed Vice President of Medical Affairs in 2011. Dr. Sandborg is also a Professor of Pediatrics and Director of Pediatric Rheumatology at the Stanford School of Medicine. Prior to joining LPCH, Dr. Sandborg was Director of Pediatric Rheumatology and Rehabilitation, Children’s Hospital of Orange County (1982 to 1997), and Assistant Clinical Professor Pediatrics and Medicine (1982 to 1986) and Associate Adjunct Professor Pediatrics and Medicine, University of California, Irvine (1986 to 1997). Dr. Sandborg earned a Bachelor of Science degree and Doctor of Medicine degree from UCLA. She completed her post-doctoral and residency training at Children’s Hospital Los Angeles. James Dunn, M.D., Ph.D. Surgeon-in-Chief; age 54. Dr. Dunn is a pediatric surgeon and bioengineer. He joined LPCH in October 2016 as Surgeon-in-Chief and Chief of the Division of Pediatric Surgery, Department of Surgery, at the Stanford School of Medicine. Dr. Dunn was previously Chief of Pediatric Surgery at Mattel Children’s Hospital at the University of California, Los Angeles (“UCLA”). Dr. Dunn earned his Bachelor of Science degree from California Institute of Technology and graduated from Harvard Medical School in 1992 with a concomitant Ph.D. in bioengineering from Massachusetts Institute of Technology. After completing his surgical fellowship training at UCLA and a pediatric surgical fellowship at Indiana University, he became a faculty member at UCLA in 2001. A-6

Existing Facility�� � ����� �� �� �(� ���� ����� �� ��� �� :4)� ��������� ��� �%�� �� ����8� )66� � �� ���� � ���*��� ��.�0����� (� ����:6� � �� ���� � � ��� �� ���� �� ������ �������� �������� 3�� ���������� ������ ���� �������� ��� �� ��� �� ���$��2� �� (���������������� ��� � ������� 3�����(� ���$��2� �� (� ���� ������� ������ � � � ������ �� �� � ���� �� �� � ������ �� 3���� ���$��2� �� (� ��������� ���� ��� 9���� (�:&8�)46:�������*��� ��.�0����� (������(������(�� ���� ��� �������� ��� ��������� �������������� ��� ���� �� �� � �������;������.�������� ������� ����2������ ���������� ��������� 2���� �� . ��� ��.��� ���)4&5� �� �� ��<�� � �� ������ ���8���� ���������� (�� �� ��� �������;���� ���� ��� ���3� �� � �� 3�� ���.� � ��� ���� �� ��� � ��� � �� =� ���� �2��(8� ��� >� E�� ?@�� � ����� �� ����� ��� � �������.� �� � � ������ ���*������ �����#������ �)4&1�������>��*��"�9*��?��� ����� ������� �� � �� �� ��� *������ ��� ��������� � �� � ��� � ��� �� ���� �� ������ ���8�3����� � �� ���� ����� ��� 3� ��� >������� � ��8� 9 �� � +�� � ��� ���� ����������?� � ��� �� ! 2���� � &8� )4&68� ������� ��� ��������� ���� � �� � � � ��� *��� ��.�0����� (������� ���� �������� ��������� �� ����� 3�� �

Mary Leonard, M.D., M.S.C.E. Physician-in-Chief, age 54. Dr. Leonard, a professor of pediatrics and of medicine, was appointed Chair of the Department of Pediatrics at the Stanford School of Medicine and Physician-in-Chief at LPCH in July 2016. Prior to joining LPCH, Dr. Leonard spent 25 years at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia (“CHOP”) and the University of Pennsylvania, first as a resident and fellow and then as a faculty member. At CHOP, Dr. Leonard directed the Office of Clinical and Translational Research and was a senior scholar in the Center for Clinical Epidemiology and Biostatistics. In 2015, Dr. Leonard was appointed associate dean of maternal and child health research, a position in which she directed the transdisciplinary child and maternal health research and training initiatives of the Child Health Research Institute. Dr. Leonard earned her Bachelor of Arts degree from Northwestern University, her Doctor of Medicine degree from Stanford School of Medicine, and her Master of Science degree in clinical epidemiology from the University of Pennsylvania. Dr. Leonard is a member of the Alpha Omega Alpha Honor Medical Society, the American Society of Clinical Investigation, the Academic Pediatric Association and the Society for Pediatric Research. FACILITIES AND PATIENT SERVICES Overview As a regional, national and international referral center for tertiary and quaternary pediatric care, the Hospital provides critical care and general pediatric medical and surgical subspecialty care to pediatric patients and obstetric services to expectant mothers. Facilities and Infrastructure Existing Facility. LPCH currently maintains a total of 302 licensed acute-care beds, 266 located at the Existing Facility and 36 located at three satellite facilities described below. The main facilities of LPCH are located on the University’s campus in Palo Alto on land owned by the University and leased to LPCH for nominal rent. The current lease between the University and LPCH expires January 31, 2063. The Existing Facility is physically connected to SHC’s hospital facilities. LPCH is in the construction and equipping phases of an extensive capital expansion and improvement program begun in 2014 to modernize its facilities, address capacity constraints and equip the Hospital with its own diagnostic and treatment platform (collectively, the “Project’”’). LPCH anticipates commencing operations in the Expansion in December 2017. See “THE PROJECT” herein for a description of the Expansion. LPCH also operates three satellite facilities, which are described below in “Affiliations, Joint Ventures and Alliances.” As of November 1, 2016, LPCH’s total licensed bed count for the Existing Facility and satellite facilities is set forth below. A-7

=>! �$?@� � �� ��� � � # �������� � ��� ��� ��� ��� �� � �<I� ��� &&%���� ! �$� ���� �� ��� ��� ���.� � ��� ��� � � � �� ��� � � �������� +����(� ,�� ���� � ��� ��I� �� )1%���� ����� ��� ���� ��� � ��� � ���� ��� A%���� ����� ��� �� ����2�� �� �� ��� � � � �� � � B�� � -�(� � ��� ���%����� ���� �������� ,������� ��� � � ��� ���� 0 ������ I���:/%����! �$8���&6%��������� ������� ��� ���� ��������A%��������� ����� ����2���� ����� �� � 9 ���,�� ����� �����B���� �� ���I�������6%����! �$�� ���;� ���� ��� ������"��3 ���� (���B� �� ��� ����� � �� �� ���E �� �2�� � ����2 �2��.���;� ���� ��� ��8����� �� �����E �� �2�� � ������� ������ �� ��� ��������� �� ��� � � � � ��� ���� ���� � �� � � ��������� ��� ������� ��������� ���� � ������� � � ���� ��� �� 2��� � 0 � � �� ��� �� � �� �� � � ����� � ��.���� �8� ���� >0�� � � *�� �!#� ��� *!�� �*"+ �*�C����������������������*���������?��� �������

����� 3��� ���*��� ��.�0����� (8�3����� ��� � �� ��� ��� ������ ���� ��(�)1/8444� �;�� �� � 8� � � %� (�� �� � ��� �� ��� �� ���$��2� �� (���������������� ��� � ��������������� �� ���$��2� �� (��� ����*��� ��.�0����� (�� ���������� ��� ���� ��� 8� � �� ��� 8�������� (��������� � �� 2����������� ���� ������� � �2�� ���� � ���� � �� 3 %� (� �� ���.� � �� � �� 3���� �(� ����� �� ����� ������� � �� ��� $��2� �� (� ��� ��E���� � � ��� *��� ��.� 0����� (�� � 0 � �� ���� �� � �� �� ��� *������ �8� ���� >��*� �"�9*��?��� �����

� �� ���(������������ ���� 3���8�������� �������(������� ������ �������� 3������ ��� ������� � ��.���� ��� ���� ����� ��� �����.���� �� ��� �����.� �� ���*������ �D�

�� ����� ������� ���� �������� ��� ���� ��(�:&8444� �;�� �� ��� � �� ������3� ���������� � ��� ��� ������ (8�3����� ��� � ���� ��� � ���*��� ��.�0����� (� � �.�� �� � �� ������3�(�� ������ ������ � ����� ���� ��� � �� � ��� �� 2����8� ��� � ���� ��3� �� �� �� (8� ��� �������� �� �� ���� �� � ����� ���� ���� �� �������� ����� ��� ���#��.� � ������ � ���

�� ������������ � �� ���$��2� �� (������� ��� ����� ������� ���� ��(�&&A8444��;�� �� ��� � �� ����������������.��� �� ����� ���� ��������� � � ���*��� ��.�0����� (������������� ���������� � � � �� ��� ������ ���������� (��� 2������

Licensed Beds Existing Facility Satellite Facilities Total Obstetrics 52 --- 52 Neonatal/Pediatrics Medical/Surgical 96 30 126 Intensive Care 44 + 44 NICU, Level 3 40 --- 40 NICU, Other 34 6 40 Total Licensed Beds 266" 36 302 (Tt is anticipated that the number of licensed beds located at the Hospital will increase from 266 beds to 361 beds upon commencement of services in the Expansion, up to 149 licensed beds of which are expected to be located in the Expansion, with the remainder expected to be located in the Existing Facility. ®) Includes 6-bed joint venture NICU at Sequoia Hospital (Redwood City), and 30-bed pediatric medical/surgical unit at El Camino Hospital (Mountain View). LPCH also manages, through separate joint ventures, a 13-bed neonatal intensive care unit (“NICU”) located at Dominican Hospital in Santa Cruz; an 11-bed NICU and perinatal diagnostic center located at Salinas Valley Memorial Hospital; a 27-bed pediatric inpatient unit and an 8-bed pediatric intensive care unit at Sutter West Bay Hospitals-California Pacific Medical Center in San Francisco; a 35-bed NICU, a 16-bed pediatric inpatient unit and an 8-bed pediatric intensive care unit at John Muir Health in Walnut Creek; and a 6-bed NICU at Sequoia Hospital in Redwood City. With the exception of the joint venture involving Sequoia Hospital, all of these joint venture beds remain on the licenses of the host hospitals and are not included in LPCH’s licensed bed complement presented above. For more information about these arrangements, see “FACILITIES AND PATIENT SERVICES—Academic and Clinical Excellence” herein. LPCH owns the Existing Facility, which is located in an approximately 275,000 square foot, four-story structure located on the University’s campus in Palo Alto on land leased from the University. The Existing Facility houses pediatric inpatient, outpatient, ancillary and support services and certain administrative functions. A two-story parking structure owned by LPCH on land leased from the University is adjacent to the Existing Facility. For a description of the Expansion, see “THE PROJECT” herein. Other physical facilities owned, leased or used by LPCH are described below and none of such arrangements are anticipated to change upon the opening of the Expansion: e LPCH leases and occupies approximately 31,000 square feet of space within SHC’s hospital facility, which is connected to the Existing Facility through a common hallway. This space houses inpatient obstetric services, the normal newborn nursery, the special care and intermediate care nurseries and the Perinatal Diagnostic Center. e LPCH leases from the University and unrelated parties approximately 118,000 square feet of space in buildings located across from and next to the Existing Facility. LPCH uses this space for outpatient pediatric specialty services. A-8

����� ��� � �� ��.� ���� � �� � ���� �� ��� *��� ��.� 0����� (� � � � ��������� 3� �� ��� � �% � �� � ��� �� � ������ � ���� ��� =>!��?@8� ��� ��� �.��� � ��� �� �� �(� �;�� ��� � ����� ���� ����2��� � � ����� 2��� ��� ���� ������������� �!���� ��������� �)4)4�� ����� � �� ��.�3 ��� ���� �� �� � ����.��������� ��.�� �%� �� � ��������� ���������������8�� ���� �������;������ �������� � ��� ���� �� ���*��� ��.�0����� (�� �-������.��� �� �� � � ��� � �� ��.���2������� ����2��� � �� �������� ���� ������� �� � � �3���� ���� �� �������.� ���� #�2�� ���� � =>����#?@�� � ���� 3 �� ��� ����.� ������� � ������<�� ��� �� � �� � �%. ��.� �� ��� � �� �� �� � � ���� � ���� 3 �� ���� ����� ��� � . ���� ������ ��� �� ��.� �� )4&6� ���� ���� �� ���3 �� ��� ����� ��� � ��� � ���� ��� � � � � ��� )4)4� ��������� � �!��� � ����������

������� �� �(� ���������8��� �� ��� �����.� �� ���*������ �8��� ����� ���� � �����.� � ��(� �� �� �� 2����� � �� ��� ��� ��� ��E ����.������ ��� ��� ������ (8� ����� ��� ��������� ��� � (8� ������� �8� � �.����(� ���� ��3� �� ������ � ���������.���� �� � �� �.�������� � �� �� � �� �� �� ��3� � ��� ��� ������ (������������� � �� �� �� ������� ��.������ ��� ��������� (8� ���� ����� ����.� ��������� 2����� �� ����� ������� ������� ��� ���������� ������ �3� �������������� (�� ���� ����(� ��� ���� 2��� �� ���� �������������

e LPCH leases from unrelated parties approximately 274,000 square feet of space in buildings in Palo Alto and Menlo Park for LPCH and PCHA outpatient and administrative functions. e LPCH owns buildings with approximately 63,000 square feet of space in Campbell, California, approximately 20 miles from the Hospital. LPCH uses this space for outpatient and administrative functions as existing tenants vacate the premises when leases expire. e LPCH owns a building with approximately 80,000 square feet of space in Sunnyvale, California, approximately 11 miles from the Hospital. In May 2016, LPCH opened 65,000 square feet of this space for outpatient pediatric specialty services and a location for a Stanford Children’s Health fertility practice. e LPCH leases from unrelated parties approximately 13,000 square feet of space in a building in Emeryville, California that houses FPO and PCHA professional practices and administrative functions. LPCH also leases from unrelated parties approximately 6,000 square feet of space in another building in Emeryville that houses FPO and PCHA professional practices and administrative functions. These buildings are approximately 44 miles from the Hospital. e LPCH also utilizes space within SHC’s hospital facility for certain administrative functions through a shared services arrangement and relies upon certain space within SHC’s hospital facility for certain purchased services, including cardiac catheterization and clinical laboratory services. Seismic Compliance. The Hospital Seismic Safety Act of the State of California (the “State of California” or the “State”) requires licensed acute care functions to be conducted only in facilities that meet specified seismic safety standards. All seismic safety standards must be met no later than 2030, and there also are intermediate milestones that must be met by earlier deadlines. Separate and distinct seismic safety standards apply to structural frame performance and for non-structural element performance. The Existing Facility of LPCH is currently designated as level SPC-3 and are compliant with the structural frame requirements, allowing use of the Existing Facility past 2030 without modification or limitation. LPCH is retrofitting discrete areas of the Existing Facility for compliance with the non- structural performance standards (“NPC”), as the regulations currently require. LPCH has received State approval to extend the deadline for NPC compliance to 2020. The retrofitting work consists of bracing and anchoring non-structural elements such as pipes, conduits and equipment in discrete areas of the Existing Facility. Building permits for the retrofitting have been received from the California Office of Statewide Health Planning and Development (““OSHPD”). The work is being phased to minimize disruption to on-going patient care operations. The work has been in progress since the spring of 2016 and all of the work is expected to be completed prior to the 2020 deadline for NPC compliance. LPCH currently relies and, upon the opening of the Expansion, anticipates continuing to rely upon services located in the adjoining SHC hospital facility, such as clinical laboratory, transfusion, pregnancy and newborn and materials management. Through SHC’s construction of a new hospital facility and planned retrofits of the existing SHC hospital facility, the areas housing the SHC services that support LPCH are expected to be made compliant with seismic safety standards by their approved extension deadlines. A-9

���� ����� ��� �� � �� ���� � .(� ���� ������� � ������ �� ��2�����.� �� �� � ���� ��3� ���� � .���� ����� �� � %����� �2�8���.�� �;���� (��� �8��������������( ���8�2� ������ ������ ����� ��� � ���� ������� � ��� ���� � ��3� �� ��� �����.� �� ���*������ �8���3��(� ���������������� %2���������� 2��� � � ��� �����.8� 3�(������.� �(� ���8� ��.� ��� ��.��.�� ���� ��� �� �. � � �� �� ��� � �+�8� �� 3 �� .����.� � �� � ��8� ���� ���� � �� � �� �(� ���8� ��������� � ������� � ��� �(� ���� ���� �� ��� % ��� ��� ���� �� 3���� ��� �������� ��� ��� ��� *������ ��� ���� ��. ����� �� ������� �� 3 �� ��� �� �� � ��� � �� �� ������ ��������� ������� (����� �������� (��� 3 ��� ���� ������ ���� ��� ����

��)4&58����������������� �2��3� ��� ��� � �.�������8���� ����� �� ���������� 3�����>Vision 2025�?������� �����3������ �� ����(���������2���� � �� ��� ��� � �.��������. ����3� ����� ���� �� ��� � E�� �������( ������2� �:44�����2������8���������.�� � ������� �8�����.� �8���(������������� ���8� �� ����� ������ �����2�� ���� � �� �� ������������� ������ �����������.������� ����������� . �������� ��(������������������ ��� 2����8��������� ��� ��������2��� ����������� ��� � ���� ��� �����+��� �� )4)/�� ���3 ������ ���������� 2� ����� � �.���. ��� ����>The Preeminent Pediatric and Obstetric Health System,?� 3� �� � ��� ��������� ���� �(��.� � � �.��� . ���8� =�@� ��2�����.� ��������� ���� ��������� ����������8� =��@� ��������.� ������� ����8� ���� =���@� � �� ��.� �� 2����%������ �(� ��8� ����� �� 3����� ��� ���� �������� 3��

�,�%�'!, ��% � !�!,� �3,� ��,�

Clinical Programs and Services.� � � � ��� � ��� ��8� ��������� �� �� � � ����� ��� ���� ����� �� � � �� ������ ��� ��(� .���<����� �����>��� � �� ��*���������?�= ���>��� � �?@������������ � ��� ���� �� � ���� ���� ����2� I� ����� � ���� �� �� ��������I� �(� ��� ��� ���� ���� ���� �� (� �������I� ����� ��� � �.��� ������ ��������I�� �.����(�������3� ���� 2����I����� ������� � � ������ ��������.���� ��.��� *���� ��� � � �� 2��� ��2� ��(� ���� �� ������(� ���� ����� ��� �� ��� �� � �� � �.� � � ��� 3 ���� � ��

Information Technology Systems. LPCH completed its multi-year strategic implementation of integrated enterprise information systems in mid-2014, which included the implementation of a full Electronic Medical Record (“EMR”) system. The enterprise-wide EMR system enables inpatient, outpatient and ambulatory service areas to work more efficiently and to coordinate patient care among LPCH and other Bay Area pediatric providers. In late 2015, HIMSS Analytics awarded LPCH its distinguished Level 7 designation for both inpatient and ambulatory services that recognized LPCH’s enterprise use of the EMR system to support the full continuum of care. In 2016, LPCH was recognized as one of the nation’s Best Hospital IT Departments by Healthcare IT News based on survey responses received from LPCH’s information technology staff ranking their satisfaction in areas such as workplace culture, organizational leadership and professional development opportunities. LPCH has also been named one of “Health Care’s Most Wired” by the American Hospital Association in 2015, 2016 and 2017. LPCH has enhanced its Enterprise Resource Planning system (payroll, human resources, general ledger and supply chain services) and developed an advanced analytics and business intelligence program that enables improved data-driven decision making for clinical and operational processes. In addition, LPCH continues to innovate by creating and implementing EMR-integrated web-based clinical decision support tools that utilize data captured in the EMR system to support clinicians to make the best decisions for their patients. An example is Premie BiliRecs which uses information recorded in the EMR system about a premature infant’s gestational age and laboratory test results and provides recommendations for management of high bilirubin levels. The outcomes from these recommendations are then analyzed to update the quality of the recommendations. The LPCH information technology team remains focused on advancing current and new technologies to support cost-effective, higher quality care, clinical analytics, virtual care and the patient experience. In connection with the opening of the Expansion, new systems such as audio-visual and video conferencing, wayfinding systems, digital signage and the integration of smart TVs, network gaming solutions, real time location systems, clinical communications systems and patient-oriented tablets will be implemented in the Expansion. The upgrades of LPCH’s network infrastructures are intended to help meet capacity and reliability network standards in the Hospital. Vision 2025 In 2014, LPCH launched a review of its strategic plan, a process that became known as “Vision 2025.” The process was initiated by LPCH’s evaluation of its strategies and goals with a focus on the Project and beyond. Over 300 individuals, including board members, managers, physicians and staff, participated in the development of refreshed plans for each of LPCH’s significant clinical programs and key clinical and support services, and updates to LPCH’s vision and mission statements. The Vision 2025 framework affirms LPCH’s overall strategic goal to be “The Preeminent Pediatric and Obstetric Health System,” with three specific underlying strategic goals, (1) advancing academic and clinical excellence, (11) expanding LPCH’s reach, and (iii) creating a value-based system, each of which is described below. Academic and Clinical Excellence Clinical Programs and Services. At the Hospital, clinical care for children and expectant mothers is primarily organized into six “Centers of Excellence” (the “Centers”). These Centers focus on brain and behavior; cancer and blood diseases; cystic fibrosis and pulmonary disease; pediatric congenital heart disease; pregnancy and newborn services; and transplantation and tissue engineering. Each Center serves severely and chronically ill pediatric patients from throughout the world. In A-10

Brain and Behavior Center (the “Brain Center”)�� �����- ������� � � ��������<��� ��� �� ��.� ��� �� �� ��� ������2�� ���� ��������� � �8�3�������(�������� � ������2����������2� ��8��� � ���8� ��� ���.8� ���.��.�8���2�� ���� 8� ����� � �� �� 2���� � ��� ���� ����� � � � ������� ������� ���� �� ��������� �� ��� �� � ��� ��.�� �� ��������8� ��������.� �������(8� �� ���� ���� ��2�� ���� ��� ��� �� �8� � 2���� � ��� �� �8� �� �� 2������ � ��� �� �8� ��� ���� �8� ��� �� � ���� ����� (� ��� �� �8� ���� ��� � ���� ��E� (8� ��� .��� ��� ��� �� �8� � ���� �� �� ���� � �.��� ��� ��� ��� �� 2 ��� �(� ��� ����� ��� � � ����� �� �� ��� � ����� �(� � �����.� �� ����2� �� � � %�� � 2�� � ��� � ���� - ���� ��� � ��� . 2� ������ � �� � ���������.���� ����� ��� �. � � ������� ���� � � ����� ��3� ����(���� (��� �� ����� . ���� 3� ���� ��� - ���� ��� � � �������� ��� ��� � � � � - ���� ��� �8� ��� �� ��.� ��� �� � � . ��� ���� ��� ��� � �� �- ������ � ������������� � �� �- ������� ��3� ���� ������� � ���� ��� ��&4������ �� �� ���!� � ��������� � �� � � ��������� ���- ������� �� �� ������������ ��.���� �� �� . ��������� ��� ���� ��� � � . ��� 3� �� ��� �2������%������ � �� ��� � � . ��� �� � � ���� ��� �������� ���� ��(���� ��� �� ��� �� � �� ��� � � � � - ���� ���� �� �� � ���� ��� ����.� ���� � �� � ���� ��� � �� � �� � ���� �2������� ���� �2���� �� ��������������� � ����;���� (������� ������� � ����� ���� 2�� ��� � �.% � �� ;���� (� �� ������ � �� ���� �� ��� - ���� ��� � ��� � . ���8� ��(���� �� �8� ��(�� � .�� �8� ��� �� .� ���������� � .�� ��3 ���� ���(�3� �������� ���� ��� �� ����� 2� � ������� �3 ���.�� �� ���� ��������� 3�� ������ ������2� �� � �� ������ ���� ���.�3� ��� ������� ��� � �����(������� �� ���������� ��� �2����2������

Bass Center for Childhood Cancer and Blood Diseases (the “Bass Center”)�������-������� � � ��� ��� �� ������2���� ��������� 2� �2�� �� ������� ������ ���3� ������� ������� ������������������ ������ (��� �. � ������� ��� ����� � �� ��� ��� ������������)1%�������� ��� ���� �=&/����� � .(H �� � .(� ���������&)�� �������� ������� �����@��� �.�3� ����� � �.� �����.� %������(�� ��� ��8������� �� �8� ���� ���� �������� � ���� -���� ��� � � ��� � ���� ��.� � ����� ��� �� ��� � ���� � ���� �� ��(� ���� ��� � ������ ���� � �������%������������� ��� ���� �� �*������� �� ��� ������, �� ����+��38������ ���������� -������� � � ��� � �������(� ����2������� ������ ��� ��� ��������<��������� ������� �������� ��� ��� ������ ������������ � �� ���� �� � �� ����

Pulmonary Medicine and Cystic Fibrosis Center (the “CF Center”)�� � ���� �0� ��� � � �� �. � �������� � ���������� (� ���� ����������������� ���� ��� ��� ����������� ���� ��� ����� �� �� ,��������� ����� � � ������� ��� �� ��2��� ������ �� � . ��� �� � � ������ �� �� �� �� ����� ���3� �� ��

addition to the services provided through the Centers, LPCH provides outreach and community service programs and a full range of medical and surgical subspecialties. Brain and Behavior Center (the “Brain Center”). The Brain Center specializes in treating disorders of brain development and function, which may manifest themselves in behavioral, emotional, learning, language, development, sensation or movement abnormalities. It combines the expertise of specialists in a broad range of diseases, including epilepsy, autism and developmental disorders, movement disorders, cerebrovascular disorders, depression, bipolar and anxiety disorders, traumatic brain injury, neurogenetic disorders, brain tumors and congenital central nervous system defects. It differentiates itself by focusing on behaviors post-intervention. The Brain Center’s governance structure is designed to support integration and collaboration efforts with psychiatry partners. Programs within the Brain Center include the Center for Brain Tumors, the eating disorder program and the Center for Brain Outcomes. The Center for Brain Tumors within this Center is one of 10 members of the National Cancer Institute’s Pediatric Brain Tumor Consortium. The eating disorder program links an inpatient program with an evidence-based outpatient program that coordinates medical and psychiatric treatment. A Center for Brain Health Outcomes is being built that can capture both retrospective and prospective data to help define national quality indicators and continue to improve the long-term quality of life. In all of the Brain Center’s programs, psychiatrists, psychologists, neurosurgeons and neurologists work closely with basic researchers to discover the inner workings of the brain and how it impacts behavior so that children coping with complex conditions may lead more full and productive lives. In fiscal year 2016, the Brain Center’s inpatient activity increased 3%, from 828 discharges in fiscal year 2015 to 853 discharges in fiscal year 2016. Forty-four percent of inpatients came from the primary service area of San Mateo and Santa Clara counties, 30% came from the surrounding eight- county Bay Area, 20% from other California counties and 6% from outside the State of California. Bass Center for Childhood Cancer and Blood Diseases (the “Bass Center”). The Bass Center offers comprehensive care and innovative therapies for children with cancer and blood diseases. This facility integrates inpatient and outpatient care and has a 27-bed inpatient unit (15 hematology/oncology beds and 12 stem cell transplant beds) along with a contiguous eight-bed day hospital, infusion room, lab and clinic. The Bass Center also has eight beds allocated to support chemotherapy inpatient infusions at the LPCH-licensed inpatient unit at El Camino Hospital in Mountain View, California. The Bass Center is staffed by individuals trained in the specialized needs of pediatric cancer patients and includes appropriate isolation rooms. The Bass Center’s program diagnoses and treats approximately 240 new cancer patients per year and performed 41 stem cell transplants in fiscal year 2016. The Bass Center’s goals are to offer a comprehensive program that will serve more patients, to develop a more robust research platform and to expand the Bass Center’s geographic reach to provide more children with access to the specialized services offered by the Bass Center. In fiscal year 2016, the Bass Center’s hematology/oncology service had a total of 1,177 inpatient discharges and the stem cell transplant service had a total of 65 inpatient discharges. The Bass Center is a strong regional program with 54% of patients coming from the primary service area of San Mateo and Santa Clara Counties, 29% from the eight surrounding Bay Area counties, 15% from other California counties and 2% from outside the State of California. Pulmonary Medicine and Cystic Fibrosis Center (the “CF Center”). The CF Center integrates an interdisciplinary team of clinicians and researchers from LPCH and the Stanford School of Medicine. Their combined efforts have produced a program that focuses on care of children with a A-11

Betty Irene Moore Children’s Heart Center (the “Heart Center”)�� � ���� ��� � ��� � ��� ����� �� ��� � � ��.� .� �� � � ����� ���� ���� ������ (� �� � ���� ���� � ��� ��� � � �� *���������� �� � �� 2���� ���������� ������ ��� ������ ���. �� � �� ����� (���B� ������� ����������� (� ������������(� ������ � ���.� ��� ���� �� � ����� �8� ����� ��� ���� ( ��.� ���� �� 3� �� � �.��� ��� ���� ��;�� ��� ��� � ��������8� ������ ���� � ��� ���� ������ ��� �;�� ��.���������<����� �� � ������� 2����� ������ � ���� ������ � �� � ���������8�� �3��.��� ��� ��� ������ 2� ������ ���8�� ����� �)A������ �� �� � ���������2� ��� ����� �� �� �� �������

��������� � ������ ��� ���� 2����(� ������ ���� � �3���&84))�����������(�� �)4&6������ ����8� �� ��3� ��/6/��� ������� .� ��������&1���� � ������� ������������ ��� �� . ��������������,��� ����� =>�, ?@8� ������� �� �� ����� ��� ���� (� ���� ��� �2�� � � �� � �� � ��� ������ � �� � �� ��� �8� �� 5�/8� ����� ��.� �����������(�� ������� ���� � ���� 2����(� ������ ���� � �� � ���������(�� �)4&68�)/N� �� �� ��� ������� � ���������� ��� (��� 2����� ��� ������,� � �������� ����� ��� �� ���8�)7N������ � �� ��� ��.� %� �� (�-�(�� ��8� :4N� ����� � �� �� � � ����3� ��������� ���� ���� &6N� ����� � �� �� �� � �������� �� �����

������ ����� ��� �� ��� ����� �� ��� �� �� ������ ���� � �3����� 2�� � ���*������ �������� >��*��"�9*��?��� ����� ����� � ������� �� � ���

Johnson Center for Pregnancy and Newborn Services (the “Johnson Center”)�������9 ��� �� ��� � ���� ���������� � �� (��� ��������.�� ���� �� � ���8����3����������� �(���3� �������� �� ��� �� ����2���� ������ � �����������������������%� ����� (�� ��� ����� �� ������

����9 ��� ����� � ��� �� 2����� ��������� ��� ������.� ���8�.��� ���� �������.8���.�� �� �� � �� �� ����� �� ������ 2����8���.�� ����� ��� ����� �8�����2� (8���� � � �������� �� ��.����� �������3� �� �� ����2���� ���� ������ � �8� ���-���2� ��%#�2�� ���� �������� ����� . ��� ��� ��� �.% � ��� �� 3% ���� ��� ��� ��. ���� ��.�� �� ���!� �� ��� � ����2���� ����� �� � ��)4&/8� ���9 ��� ����� � ���.��� ��� ��.� �� ��� (� ���� �� ��� �2�� ���� �� �� 2����8� ���� � 2����.� �� ����� ��.�� �� �� 2����� � �� � �% � ���� � �� ��� ��������( ������

plethora of respiratory and pulmonary conditions, from the common and simple to the complex and rare. The CF Center is one of the largest care providers for children with conditions such as cystic fibrosis, asthma, chronic lung disease of infancy resulting from premature birth and immature lungs, acute or chronic respiratory infections, multi-system disorders that affect breathing and lungs such as cerebral palsy, neuromuscular diseases such as spinal muscular atrophy and other muscular dystrophies, as well as other genetic and metabolic disorders that impact swallowing and breathing. In addition, the Center is home to a dedicated pediatric sleep program and operates one of the few active lung transplant programs in the United States dedicated exclusively to children. Betty Irene Moore Children’s Heart Center (the “Heart Center”). The Heart Center’s mission is to bring together professional and facility resources under one Center of Excellence that serves both LPCH’s local patients and the greater community. With a multidisciplinary team specially trained to diagnose and treat infants, children and young adults with congenital and acquired heart diseases, the Heart Center cares for children requiring specialized cardiothoracic services on a national and international basis, drawing patients from all over California, at least 28 different states and several different countries. The program goals are centered on continuing the integration and expansion of the clinical, administrative and academic activities to better serve LPCH’s pediatric population in cardiology, cardiac surgery, cardiac intensive care, cardiac anesthesia and cardiac imaging. Additionally, LPCH continues to focus on early identification of cardiac anomalies through LPCH’s Fetal Echocardiography Program, in conjunction with the Center for Fetal and Maternal Health. LPCH’s Ventricular Assist Device Program continues to grow to care for children most critically ill with advanced heart failure and implanted 43 ventricular assist devices over the past three years. LPCH added the HeartWare system to its armamentarium of implantable devices in appropriate cases, which allows for the early discharge of patients on ventricular assist devices to a home setting while patients wait for their heart transplant. With seven Board-certified providers, LPCH’s Adult Congenital Heart Disease (““ACHD”’) Program has more Board-certified providers than any other ACHD program in the United States. The number of inpatients served by the Heart Center was 1,022 in fiscal year 2016. Of these, there were 565 cardiac surgeries and 17 heart transplants. The inpatient program had a Case Mix Index (“CMI”), a measure of pediatric acuity and relative costs or resource needs to treat patients, of 4.5, reflecting the medically complex population served by the Heart Center. In fiscal year 2016, 25% of patients came from LPCH’s primary service area of San Mateo and Santa Clara counties, 29% came from the eight-county Bay Area, 30% came from other areas within California and 16% came from other states and countries. It is anticipated that certain components of the Heart Center will move to the Expansion. See “THE PROJECT” herein for additional information. Johnson Center for Pregnancy and Newborn Services (the “Johnson Center”). The Johnson Center encompasses maternity care and high risk obstetrics, as well as healthy newborn and neonatal intensive care built on a successful academic-community hospital partnership. The Johnson Center’s services include prenatal diagnosis, genetic counseling, high resolution fetal ultrasound services, high risk prenatal care, delivery, lactation and parenting support and newborn intensive care. In addition, the Behavioral-Developmental Pediatrics program offers long-term follow- up for patients graduating from the Neonatal Intensive Care unit. In 2015, the Johnson Center began offering fertility and reproductive health services, and providing a full range of services from pre- conception to birth and beyond. A-12

����9 ��� ����� � �!� �� ��� � ����2���� ����� ��� 2����� ��� ��&8/&4����� ��� ������������(�� � )4&6�3� �� ��� �2� �.�� ���. �� �� � �(� �� &)�A� ��(��� ���� ����� ���� ��� �8� 6AN�3� �� � �� ��� � ��� (� �� 2����� ��8�3� ��)1N�� ���.�� �� �����.� %� �� (�-�(�� �������5N�� �� � ����� ���-�(�� ����

Pediatric Transplant Center (the “Pediatric Transplant Center”).�� ��������� ���� ������� � ��� � �������� � ��������� ���� ������� �2 �����3� ��� �� ����)/�(�� �� ������ �������� � ���.�� �� ����&8644������ ��� .��� ������� ����#� ��� �� ���� .���� �� ���� ������ ������� � � ��!� 3 �� �� 3� �� 8� � ��)4&&� �)4&68������������ � ����� ������� ��� .��� ������� �� ������(� �� � $������������ ��� � �� � ���� ����� ��� � ������� � ��� � � ���� ��� ��� �� ��� ��� � �� ��� � � � � ���� � � ��� ������� �����������8�3����� �;�� ����.��(���������<����� ���� �� ���9���� (�)4&1������ �����"�.�� (� ��� ������� �"������� �� ������8�������������(� ������� ������ ������ � � ��%(�� �. �� ��� 2�2������ ��� �� � ���

������� �� .� ��� �� � �� �� �� ��� ��2� � ���� �� �� ����� ������� �� ���� � ������� .��� ������� �8���������.���2� %�����(8���2� %��� 8� ��2� %���.8�������� �%2���� ��� ������� ��� ������� .����� ���� � ���<����-�%��� ��� ����� � � �� ���� ��.��� ��� � � � .���� � ��� ����� ��� � � � � �� ���� ������<�� ��� 3�� ��.� �� � �� � � ������� �8� 3����� �� ��� ��(� ��� ������ ��� ������� � �������� � ���� ����� ��� �������(� ������� �� ���3� ���3� �������(������ ��� ���� �8������ ��3� �������(������ �� ������� �(� � �� � ��� ��� ���� ���� �� ��� � ��� (� �(� ��8� ����� ���3� ����E � 2������ � �� ������� � ������� �8��� ��� ��3� ���2���������.��(������ �<���� ��� � � ������� �� � ������� �8������ �� �� �� (��.���� ������� ���3� ����E ������(������ ����

Genomics, and Definitive and Curative Medicine.������������ �� ��.�3� �� ���$��2� �� (����� ���� �� 3 ���.������� �������2�� ���.�������������� ���� ���� . ���D��'�� ����8�����#����� �2������ �� � �2��,��������� � �� �.�� ����� �� �� �����8� ����� �� ����� � � ���� �� ��� ���� �� .�� ����� 8� �� �.� �� � ���.�8�����.������2������<��� �� ��� �� � ��������� � ����(���� 2���� ��� � � � ������ ����� ��� �����������'�� ������� 2���������� ������������� �(�)4&A��(�� ��.��.� ���B� ���*� ��� ��;������.� �� ��� �� ���� ���� �� � � � � � �� ��%� ����� � ���� ��� � � � � #����� �2�� ���� �� � �2�� ,�������� 3��� � �� ��� > � �� �� ��� ���� ����?� ���� � 2���� ����� ���� .���� �� ������ � �� ��� �� 3� �� ����� �.8� ������ � �2�� ��������8� 3� �� ��� �� �� � � � ����� �� ��� .��� ��� �� ������� ������.� � ��� � ��� � ������� �.��� �� ����� � ���� ���� ������� ����������� �� �� � �8� ������ � �� �#����� �2������ �� � �2�� ,�������� ���� ������ � ��� �� � %��%������ ��������� ����� 3� �� � �� ��� ��� ��2�� ���� � ���������

Professional Services. ���� 0��� ����� �2��(� ���� � ��� ��� ��� �������� . ��� � � ����� (� ��(��������3� � � �� ���� ����� ���� � �� � ����� ��2� � 644� ��(��������3� � � �� �� � �� ��� 0��� ����� 2� �&64���(��������������2������� �� ����� 2��� ��3� �� ���� � ������� .� �� �� ���� 3����� ���

The Johnson Center also manages several clinical outreach services in maternal-fetal medicine, providing early diagnosis and consultative services for high risk maternity care throughout the region, including Redwood City, Mountain View, Fremont, Salinas and Santa Cruz. The Johnson Center continues to lead in the development and evaluation of simulation training, both in the laboratory and on-site. Simulation training provides staff and the community an opportunity to learn in a supported environment. Obstetric discharges from the Johnson Center increased 2.66% to 4,869 in fiscal year 2016 compared to the prior year discharges of 4,743. In fiscal year 2016, the average length of stay for obstetric patients was 3.4 days. Obstetric patients from the primary service area counties of San Mateo and Santa Clara accounted for 86% of obstetric discharges. Twelve percent of patients came from the eight Bay Area counties and 2% from other California counties. The Johnson Center Neonatal Intensive Care unit served a total of 1,510 inpatients in fiscal year 2016 with an average length of stay of 12.8 days. Of these inpatients, 68% were from the primary service area, with 27% coming from the eight-county Bay Area and 4% from outside the Bay Area. Pediatric Transplant Center (the “Pediatric Transplant Center”). The Pediatric Transplant Center is a national leader in transplant volume with more than 25 years of experience performing more than 1,600 pediatric organ transplants. Data from the Organ Procurement and Transplantation Network show that, from 2011 to 2016, LPCH has performed more pediatric organ transplants than any other U.S. medical center. The Pediatric Transplant Center has become a destination center for the most acute and complex cases, which require highly specialized care. In the January 2017 Scientific Registry of Transplant Recipients release, LPCH’s kidney transplants had the best three-year graft survival in the nation. LPCH’s surgeons perform isolated liver and intestinal transplants and combined organ transplants, including liver-kidney, liver-heart, liver-lung, and multi-visceral transplants. The surgical team utilizes ABO-incompatible donors and segmental donor organs to increase the donor pool and minimize the waiting period for transplants, which ultimately increases the transplant success rate. LPCH offers kidney transplants to newborns with kidney failure from birth, infants with kidney failure caused by structural abnormalities of the urinary system, children with major vascular anomalies or accidents, patients who have been highly sensitized from prior transplants or transfusion, and mothers carrying unborn children with major kidney defects. Genomics, and Definitive and Curative Medicine. LPCH is partnering with the University and SHC on two significant and developing clinical and research programs: Genomics, and Definitive and Curative Medicine. Through these partnerships, LPCH intends to focus on the use of genomics to, among other things, assign individualized treatment protocols and materially improve patient outcomes. The Stanford Clinical Genomics Service plans to launch in early 2018 by bringing the Whole Exome Sequencing bioinformatics and interpretation in-house. The Center for Definitive and Curative Medicine was created “to cure the incurable” and provide cell and gene therapies to patients with lifelong, debilitative diseases, with the intent to eradicate the genetic anomalies causing those conditions. Through its translational research expertise and infrastructure, the Center for Definitive and Curative Medicine has opened three first-in-human clinical trials with more in the development pipeline. Professional Services. The FPO effectively functions as the medical group for faculty physicians who practice pediatrics or obstetrics. Over 600 physicians who are part of the FPO and over 160 physicians and advanced practice providers who are part of PCHA together are known in the A-13

���� ������ ,������� ������ � � � ����� ���� ��� ������ ������� � �2�� ������ � � � ��(������� � �� ������ �� ��� ������� ��������� ������������*���� �2�������� � ������� .� �� �����.��� �� ���0�����������������(�� ��ex-officio � � ������� �� ����������� ���������,������������� �� � ������������� �� ��� ������ ������ � �� ���- � �� ��#� �� �� ������� ��,�������' ���������0��� �����������2������� �� ������������ ������������ �� ���(� ���=*���@������� �������� � ��)4&58� �������.� �� ��� ��������� �� �. � � �� ���� �� �� � ���� � ��� � ���� � ��� ������� ��������� �� ��(������� !� 3 ��� � �� ����������.�����(�������� �� ����3� ������.����� �� .���<� � ���������� .���<� � ���� ���.���� ��������.���� ����� � ������;��������� ������� (������ ����� (���(�������� �� �����3����� ��� ����� ��.�� ���� �� �;���� (������ ���� ��� ���� �����

Packard Children’s Health Alliance and Packard Medical Group. ��)4&&8���������� ��� ����� ��,�������' ���3� �� � ���� ���� .� �� � ��(� �� � �� ��� ���������� � ���� � ��� ���� �� ��� �� � ����� ������ 2������. ����� ��� 3������������������ ��,�������' �������(��������3� ���� ��� �� � ���������� ������� (���� �� �������� ��,�������' �������������������� ��� ������� (�� � ��������� �� �� �����(���������� �� ���8���������.����� (���� �� ����� ����

����� ���� ����� .���<��� � �� � �� � ����� (%������ ����� ��� ���� �� � ���� � �� ����� � �.� � � ��� -�(� � ���� � ���� �E�� �2��� �� ����� � �� � ���� � ��� 2� ���� � ��� �� ����� ����� ���� ����(�������!� 3 ���(��������.���� ������� ���. 3��.��� 2����� ���8� ��������.������ � ������ ��������� ���� ��� � . ���� ���� ��������.� ��� ;���� (� ���� � ���� � �� �� �� �� �� ��� ����� �� � �� �� �� ��.����

������ 3���������� 2� �&64���(��������������2������� �� ����� 2��� �����))�� �� ������ �:7� � �� � ��� � ���� ��� ���� 0 ������ � -�(�� ���� � ����� ��� � �� � ��� ��2�� �� ��� � ��� ������� ����� ���� �� ������� (� �� 2����� ��� � �� ��� ���� ��8� *�� (2����8� 0 �� � 8� , � � �(� ���� B���� � � ������ ��2� ��� �� ��������� �� ����� � 2���� � ����� ���� �� 2����� � �������0 ������ ������ ���+�� � �8� ��������� � ��� � ������� ���+�� � �8�����������>*������ �� ���������"����?���� 3������������ ���������.���� ���2���� ���. ��� ���2����� ��� ������� ��������� ����(������� ������=�� �� ������ �0��@�3� ����&4������� ���2� (������(���� ���-�(�� ����� ���������(�� �)4&68������� �� ����� �� ���� 2� �)/48444�2��� ���

��������� �� � ��� �� � �� �� �� ������. ����� �3� �� ����8�3�� ������������� �. ���� � � 2����������.�� � �����2�� ���� ����� ��� �� � � �� �����������(�������� �� ����8� ��������.���(� �� � �� � ��.�� ������������� ���������� � ��� �� � �� 3�������� ������������(������ �� � ��.������ �� 3���� ���������(�� �)4&68������� 2�����F7�5������ �� ���������������.�� � �� � � ����������� ����� ����! ��&� ��� ������� ���� �� ���� ��� ���������� � � ���� �� �������� ������������������-� � ���� ���������� � ���� ��

�3+���!#� #) ������ ���,&

��� ��������� ���� ���������+��� ��)4)/���� ����� ���� �� ��� ���������� �����������2� ��.���.�% � ������ (� �� �� � � �� � ���� ���� �.� ���� � ����� ���� � �.�� �� �� ������3� �� �� � � ��� ���� ���� ��(������������������� ��� ���� ������� �� ���� ���� ��������� ������ ���������� (��� ����� ���. �� � � ����0 ������ �-�(�� ������� � ��� ������������ �� �. � � ��3� ��� 2��� �� �� � 3� %���� (��� ��� � �� ���� � �8������� 2����� � ���������� ����� (��� 2����� . �������

marketplace as the “Stanford Children’s Health Physician Network.” This network provides professional services at all Stanford Children’s Health locations. In fiscal year 2016, the FPO provided 250,862 visits, an increase of 8.51% from 231,182 visits in fiscal year 2015. The Chief Medical Officer for LPCH and the Chief Administrative Officer for Physician Practices for Stanford Children’s Health and Chief Executive Officer of PCHA together manage both the FPO and PCHA. They are ex-officio board members of PCHA and the Chief Medical Officer for LPCH is a shareholder and President of the Board of Directors of Packard Medical Group. The FPO and PCHA have been on the same electronic medical record system (Epic) since the summer of 2014, enabling close clinical integration and care coordination. The Stanford Children’s Health Physician Network contracts as a single physician practice with managed care organizations. This organizational alignment is designed to support the unique needs of faculty and community physician practices while also ensuring consistent quality and standards of care. Packard Children’s Health Alliance and Packard Medical Group. In 2011, PCHA and the Packard Medical Group were formed and together they operate as a medical foundation. There is a professional services agreement between PCHA and Packard Medical Group. Physicians who become part of PCHA become employees of the Packard Medical Group and PCHA assumes responsibility for all aspects of the physicians’ practice, including employee practice staff. PCHA has been organized to operate community-based pediatric and obstetrics practices throughout the Bay Area. The objectives of PCHA are to support the overall Stanford Children’s Health Physician Network by building a presence in growing service areas, expanding education and clinical research programs and enhancing the quality and coordination of care across different care settings. PCHA now includes over 160 physicians and advanced practice providers in 22 practices at 39 locations around the San Francisco Bay Area. PCHA also operates five of the Stanford Children’s Health specialty services centers in Capitola, Emeryville, Fremont, Monterey and Walnut Creek. Several of the PCHA practices provide professional services to the San Francisco Pediatric Venture, LLC and Contra Costa Pediatric Venture, LLC. See “Expansion of LPCH’s Reach” below. LPCH and PCHA management have set a goal to have a Stanford Children’s Health physician office (either PCHA or FPO) within 10 miles of every family in the Bay Area. In fiscal year 2016, PCHA practices recorded over 250,000 visits. LPCH has entered into a Sponsorship Agreement with PCHA, wherein LPCH has agreed to provide funding for the development and the operation of PCHA’s physician practices, including any net operating losses and capital expenditures that otherwise cannot be funded by PCHA operating cash flows. In fiscal year 2016, LPCH provided $9.4 million to PCHA in funding for operations and capital. See Note | in the audited consolidated financial statements of LPCH attached as Appendix B to this Official Statement. Expansion of LPCH’s Reach A principal focus of LPCH’s Vision 2025 is the extension of its capabilities in delivering high- complexity care to its local and regional communities through partnerships with other hospitals and physicians. These efforts are intended both to address the need for pediatric specialty care in the greater San Francisco Bay Area and to increase LPCH’s integration with providers of lower-acuity care. In addition, LPCH provides outreach and community service programs. A-14

San Francisco Pediatric Venture, LLC������������������ � �� �������0 ������ ������ ��� +�� � �8� ���8� �� ����� ���� ���� ��� ������� (� � ����(� � ���� 3� �� �� � � B�� � -�(� � ��� ���% ����� ������������,���������� � � =>��,�?@� ����� �������� �� � ����,��������� ��� ���� ��� � ��� � ���� � �$� � � ��� ��,�� ������� � �� ��� ��� ���� 0 ������ � ���� ����� ���� ���� �� � �� ��� � ��� ������� ��������� �� � �� ��� ������ ������������� (����������������� � ��� �� ����2�� � ����� ����� ���������������� ����� 2���� ��� ��.��� ���,��3� �� ���. ��� ����������.�������� 2��.� ������� ���.��;���� (������ � %����� �2������� ����� ���������� ��������0 ������ �� �- ������� ������,����2����/4N��� � �� ���� �������0 ������ ������ ���+�� � �8������

Sequoia MFM Operating Company, LLC�� � ����� ��� �� ����� � �� ��� ��;� ��� ,0,� ��� � ��.�� ����(8����8������� ���������� (�� ����(�� ����3� ��#�.�� (����� ��� ��.���������� �����;� ���� ��� ��� ���"��3 ���� (�� ������� � ��� �� ���2�� � ����� ����� �������� �� � �� ��� ! �$������� ��� ������.� � ������ � �� ���;� ���� ��� �������������� ���! �$� ���� ������������ ���.��;���� (������ � %����� �2��! �$��� �����"��3 ���� (�������! �$������� ���;� ���� ��� ��� � ����������� ������������������������������/1N��� � �� �����#�.�� (����� ��������5:N��� � �� ���� ��;� ���,0,���� � ��.�� ����(8�������

Other Satellite Facilities�� � ����� �� � ��� �� :4%���� ����� ��� �������H�� .����� ��� � ��� �� ��������������(������� �*������� �� ��� ������, �� ����+��3������� �� ����������� ����������� �� �������� ��� ������������

Affiliations, Joint Ventures and Alliances. Currently, LPCH is a member of five joint ventures with hospitals in the San Francisco Bay Area, each formed for the purposes of establishing and operating pediatric care units on the site of the partnering hospitals. LPCH also operates a satellite pediatric facility at El Camino Hospital in Mountain View. NICU Operating Company of Santa Cruz, LLC. LPCH is a member of NICU Operating Company of Santa Cruz, LLC, a California limited liability company formed with Dignity Health, a California nonprofit public benefit corporation, to maintain and operate a Level H and Level HI NICU at Dominican Hospital in Santa Cruz. Both LPCH and Dignity Health have a 50% interest in the NICU Operating Company of Santa Cruz, LLC. Through this joint venture, LPCH provides professional services coverage to the NICU at Dominican Hospital. SVMHS/LPCH NICU Joint Venture, LLC. LPCH is a member of SVMHS/LPCH NICU Joint Venture, LLC, a California limited liability company formed with Salinas Valley Memorial Healthcare System, a health care district (“SWMHS”), to maintain and operate SVMHS’s NICU and to establish a Level HI NICU and a perinatal diagnostic center at the SVHMS hospital facility located in Salinas. Both LPCH and SVMHS have a 50% interest in SVMHS/LPCH NICU Joint Venture, LLC. Through this joint venture, LPCH provides professional services coverage to the NICU and Perinatal Center at SVMHS. San Francisco Pediatric Venture, LLC. LPCH is a member of the San Francisco Pediatric Venture, LLC, a California limited liability company formed with Sutter West Bay Hospitals- California Pacific Medical Center (““CPMC”) to maintain and operate CPMC’s pediatric inpatient unit and PICU at the CPMC campus located in San Francisco and to maintain and operate the Stanford Children’s Health outpatient pediatric subspecialty clinics. The purpose of this venture is to maintain and enhance the service offerings at CPMC with the goal of expanding and improving access to high quality and cost-effective pediatric care in and around San Francisco. Both LPCH and CPMC have a 50% interest in the San Francisco Pediatric Venture, LLC. Contra Costa Pediatric Venture, LLC. LPCH is a member of the Contra Costa Pediatric Venture, LLC, a limited liability company formed with John Muir Health (“John Muir’) to maintain and operate John Muir’s pediatric services in Walnut Creek. In addition to an eight-bed PICU opened in April 2015, services include a pediatric inpatient unit, a NICU, a pediatric Emergency Department and other inpatient and outpatient services dedicated to the care of pediatric patients, excluding outpatient rehabilitation and behavioral health. The purpose of the venture is to maintain and enhance the service offerings at John Muir with the goal of expanding and improving access to high quality and cost-effective pediatric care in and around Walnut Creek and the San Francisco East Bay region. Both LPCH and John Muir have a 50% interest in the Contra Costa Pediatric Venture, LLC. Sequoia MFM Operating Company, LLC. LPCH is a member of the Sequoia MFM Operating Company, LLC, a limited liability company formed with Dignity Health doing business as Sequoia Hospital in Redwood City. The purpose of the venture is to maintain and operate the NICU and perinatal diagnostic center at Sequoia Hospital and expand the NICU to increase access to high quality and cost-effective NICU care in Redwood City. The NICU beds at Sequoia Hospital are included on LPCH’s license. LPCH has a 57% interest and Dignity Health has a 43% interest in Sequoia MFM Operating Company, LLC. Other Satellite Facilities. LPCH operates a 30-bed pediatric medical/surgical unit in a space leased by LPCH at El Camino Hospital in Mountain View. All of these beds are included on LPCH’s hospital license. A-15

� �%&6�

Future Development�� � ����� � � ��� ���(� �2���� ��� ��3� ��������� �� ��� ���8� 3����� ��(� ���� ����������� � ��8���;���� � ��8�E �� �2�� � ��� �� � �� ����� ��.���� ��3� �� �� ����� �� �� �� � 2��� �� � ��� �� �� � ��.� �� ���� ��.� ��� � �������� � �������3���������� � ��.���� �� � ������� �� � �� �� � ��.� ������ ��.� ��� � ���������(���2 �2������������� ��� ��� ���(������ � �� ��� � ���8�3�������(������ � ��������� �� ��

Outreach Programs����������������� ������� �� � �������������� ��� �� ���� ��� ����� �� �� ,�������� ��2�� �� ��������� �� �� 3 �� �� � ����� � . ���� � �� 3� ���� ������� � ��� (� ���� ��� ��� (��� 2����� �������� � �.� � � ���� � ������ ���3�� � ��$�� ���� � ���� �0 ������� �� � �� �� �������� ��� (�������� ��� (��� 2����� ���8� ����>�*"+ �*��"*���!#���,�*� � �!?��� ������ ������ � ����� � . ���� .��� ���(� ��� � �� 2����� �� �� � ���� � ������ � � �.�� ��� ������ � � �� � ��.���� � ��� � �� ��� � �������� � ������ �(� ��(�������� � �� ������� �������� � ����� � 0 � ! �$8� ����� ��� �� �� 2������ � �� .� (8� � ��� ���� � �� 2����� ���� � ��� �� .����� ������� ���8� �� 2����� � �� � 2��������������� ��� ��� ��.�� �� ����� (�� ��� ������� �������� ��� � �� ��� ��� .������� 2������ �� ��� ��2��������� �� ����� (�� ��� ���������� � ������ . ����� �3� �� ��� �� � ��������������� �� ��� ���������� ���8����������� 2����� ��(�� ���������� �� �������.�� ������� . �����

Community Service Programs.� � ����� ���� ����� �� � ��� ��� � � � ����� (� �� 2���� �(� �� 2��.� ��� �� �� � ��� � � ���� �� �� �� �� 2����8� ��� �� � �� ���� ���� � � � ��� ������ �� 3� ���� � �� � ��� (�������� ��� (��� 2����� ������*�������� ����E �� ����� (������� �� . �����������D�

Future Development. LPCH continuously evaluates new business opportunities, which may result in affiliations, acquisitions, joint ventures or contractual arrangements with other health care providers or the restructuring of existing relationships. Such new business arrangements or expansion or restructuring of existing relationships may involve financial commitments by LPCH to other entities, which may be material in amount. Outreach Programs. LPCH and pediatric and obstetrical specialists from the Stanford School of Medicine have established a network of outreach programs both within LPCH’s primary and secondary service areas and throughout the State and the western United States. For a description of LPCH’s primary and secondary service areas, see “SERVICE AREA AND COMPETITION” herein. These outreach programs generally offer services on a consult basis or through an office hours arrangement in outpatient clinics staffed by physicians from LPCH’s medical staff. For NICU, pediatric cardiovascular surgery, hospitalist services and some surgical specialties, services are provided in an inpatient setting at community hospitals. Some pediatric outpatient surgical services are also available at community hospitals. The outreach programs draw on the resources and skills of the clinical staff, and LPCH provides only nominal indirect funding for such programs. Community Service Programs. LPCH maintains a commitment to community service by serving as a resource for health care services, information and support for the residents within its primary and secondary service areas. Examples of major community benefit programs include: e Operation of a mobile medical clinic providing comprehensive primary care to homeless and uninsured youth in three San Francisco Bay Area counties e Financial support to build pediatric and obstetric capacity in three federally-qualified health centers in San Mateo County and limited financial support for a community health clinic in the north part of Santa Clara County that services a low income population e Financial support for the children’s health insurance program in Santa Cruz County e Financial support for health services for a nonprofit organization on the coast of San Mateo County e Financial and technical support for a community collaborative seeking to improve the social and emotional health of youth in Palo Alto e Leadership and financial support as the lead agency for the Safe Kids Coalition for Santa Clara and San Mateo counties e Provision of numerous prenatal, perinatal, parenting and community health education programs for the general community Value-Based Systems LPCH is evaluating and developing value-based and population health management capabilities to improve its delivery system’s quality, safety and outcomes and meet the service, costs and access expectations of patients and their families. LPCH participates in various value-based contracting and accountable care organization opportunities, including the Stanford Health Care Alliance (“SHCA”) led by SHC. SHCA was launched in 2014 as a narrow network product offered to employees of LPCH, SHC and the University. In 2015, certain self-insured technology firms also began offering SHCA to A-16

���� � �� 3��.� ����� �� 3�� ��� ����� ��� ������ .��� ���� �� ��� � ��(�� � � ��� ������� � (�� �� ������ #������ � :&8� )4&:8� )4&5� ���� )4&/� = ��� � � � �� �� � ������� ��� �� � �� �2�������� � �.�� ����#@�� � ���*��� ��.�0����� (8�� � ���� ��� ����3� �� �����.��� ������ � ������� ��������� .���� �

their employees. Enrollment in SHCA has doubled to over 20,000 members since its inception, and now includes enrollment of employees of unrelated entities. For a discussion of risks associated with integrated delivery systems, see “BONDHOLDERS’ RISKS—Business Relationships and Other Business Matters—Integrated Delivery Systems” in the forepart of this Official Statement. SERVICE AREA AND COMPETITION The Hospital serves as a community pediatric and obstetric hospital for nearby residents and a regional, national and international referral center for tertiary and quaternary care. LPCH’s primary service area consists of San Mateo and Santa Clara Counties, and its secondary service area consists of Alameda, Contra Costa, Monterey, San Benito, San Francisco, San Joaquin, Santa Cruz and Stanislaus Counties. The primary service area is approximately 1,700 square miles and, in 2016, had an estimated population of 2.6 million, including approximately 608,000 children under the age of 18. The secondary service area comprises more than 9,500 square miles and, in 2016, had an estimated population of 5.6 million, including approximately 1.3 million children under the age of 18. The following table sets forth the origin of LPCH’s obstetric and pediatric patient days by service area for each of the past three fiscal years. Origin of Patient Days” Fiscal Year Ended August 31, Pediatrics 2014 2015 2016 Primary Service Area 44% 43% 41% Secondary Service Area 33 33 32 Other 23 24 27 Total 100% 100% 100% Obstetrics 2014 2015 2016 Primary Service Area 81% 77% 81% Secondary Service Area 16 19 16 Other 3 4 3 Total 100% 100% 100% () Excludes well newborns. Source: LPCH records. LPCH competes with local community providers of general obstetrics care and competes on a regional and national basis in tertiary and quaternary services such as pediatric cardiovascular surgery and kidney and liver transplantation. Based on data derived by LPCH from information reported by OSHPD, LPCH is the market leader in share of pediatric discharges for patients from LPCH’s primary service area. The following table shows total pediatric discharges and patient days for the calendar years ended December 31, 2013, 2014 and 2015 (the most current public information available through OSHPD) for the Existing Facility, for the hospitals with the highest number of pediatric discharges for A-17

��������� �2��������������� ����� ����� �������� �� ����� ��&8&/:���(�������8�774� ��3� �� ��2�� ������.���� �� ��� ��� � ���� ��� ����� �� ��,������������� �� ������� ��������� ������� ���8� ����&6:� ��3� ��� ��� ����� (���(�������� ���� �2� ��� �� ����� ���� �� 9����&8�)4&18� �� �2���������� � ���� � �� ����� ���54� ������� ���8� ����A/N�3� ��� � �%�� ������� ����� ����� �� ������ ���.��� 2����� ���� � ���� ��� �� � �� �� �� �2�� �������� � ���� ����� �� �(� ��������� ������� (�

As a regional and national referral center for tertiary and quaternary services, the Hospital provides services to acutely ill pediatric patients with complex medical conditions. Pediatric patients from outside LPCH’s primary and secondary areas account for approximately 26% of LPCH’s patient days. The table below shows the CMI, a measure of pediatric acuity, at the Existing Facility and at the other stand-alone children’s hospitals in California for the calendar years ended December 31, 2013, 2014 and 2015 (the most current public information available through OSHPD). Hospital 2013 2014 2015 Lucile Packard Children’s Hospital 2.042 2.057 2.123 Children’s Hospital Los Angeles 1.791 1.790 1.850 Rady Children’s Hospital - San Diego 1.530 1.565 1.584 Valley Children’s Healthcare (formerly known as 1.550 1.559 1.568 Children’s Hospital Central California) Children’s Hospital of Orange County 1.407 1.430 1.473 Miller Children’s Hospital Long Beach 1.304 1.298 1.555 UCSF Benioff Children’s Hospital Oakland 1.285 1.290 1.272 (formerly known as Children’s Hospital & Research Center Oakland) Children’s Hospital of Orange County at Mission 1.295 1.223 1.163 Hospital Source: 2013-2015 OSHPD Private Datasets; ages 0-17. Excludes normal newborn, dental, psychiatry, burn, rehabilitation, OB and unknown ungroupable DRGs. MEDICAL AND PROFESSIONAL STAFF LPCH’s active medical and professional staff is comprised of 1,153 physicians, 990 of whom have teaching appointments at the Stanford School of Medicine and practice in the field of pediatrics, and 163 of whom are community physicians in private practice. As of June 1, 2017, active medical staff practiced in 40 specialties, and 85% were board-certified. The table on the next page provides additional information on active medical staff members’ by _ clinical specialty. A-19

� �

EDUCATION, TRAINING AND RESEARCH Education The Hospital serves as the primary pediatric teaching hospital of the Stanford School of Medicine. As of August 31, 2016, the Existing Facility served as a training facility for approximately 62 full time equivalent (“FTE”) pediatric residents and approximately 118 FTE post-doctoral fellows pursuing training in clinical specialties. These figures include the obstetrical and pediatric surgical residents and fellows, as well as residents and fellows who rotate to the Existing Facility from adult programs. LPCH’s Graduate Medical Education program, which is accredited by the Accreditation Council Programs of the American Medical Association, is affiliated with the Stanford School of Medicine. LPCH runs the pediatric residency program and pays the salaries and benefits of participating residents and a portion of the salary and benefits of the director of the program as well as the salary and benefits of other faculty who train the residents. As part of its mission, LPCH subsidizes the costs of training physicians and residents in its clinics and inpatient areas. Some of these costs are offset by funds received from the federal Graduate Medical Education program. During the fiscal year ended August 31, 2016, LPCH received approximately $7.7 million in Graduate Medical Education funding, which offset some, but not all, of LPCH’s costs to support the LPCH Graduate Medical Education program. For a discussion of Graduate Medical Education funding, see “BONDHOLDERS’ RISKS—Business Relationships and Other Business Matters—Children’s Hospital Graduate Medical Education Program” in the forepart of this Official Statement. Training Programs The Hospital serves as a center for graduate and postgraduate education sponsored by the Stanford School of Medicine. Interns, residents and fellows sponsored by LPCH and the Stanford School of Medicine are involved in research and patient care at the Hospital through their fellowships or participation in pediatric rotations in the approved programs on the following page. A-22

����� ���� ��� � ��� �� ��� �� ��,�������� �� ��������� ��� ������ ���� �� "���� ��� �� � � �� =>��" ?@8���� ��� �� �2�� ��������(������� � �(�����. �� ��3� ���. ��� ��� � ������ � ����2������� � ��� ������������ � �������� �� ���� ���� ���������� ���� ��� ����� �� ��,������������" ���� ������ � � � � � ���� ����(�� ���<��.� ������ 2� � ������� ���� � .��������.���2�� �����(������ (�� � ���� ��� �� ��� �� ��,�����������3������� ��� �� �$��2� �� (���� ������������� � �� ���- � �� ����������� ��� ������ *���� �2�� ������ � �� ����� �� ���� � ����� �� ��� ��" � ' 2� ���.� - � �8� 3����� �� �� ��� � � �.��� � � � ���� � � ��" �� � ���� ��" �' 2� ���.� - � �� ��� � ���� �� � � (� ������ ���� ������ ��� �.� ���.� ��� ���� �� ������ � ���� � �� � ��� � ���" 8� ��� ��� ������3� �� ��� � � ���3������� � ���� >��*"�� !'��!#�0 !�!� ��� !0�",�� �!C"��� ����� (�� ����� � ��C� ����� � ���3� �� ���$��2� �� (?��� �������

����*��� ��.�0����� (�3�������.������� ���&7A4�� ���� �� �� ��� 3%���� (������ ����� ��� �� � �� ���� ����� ����� (��� �3������ ���2��� ���� �� ������3 ���� ��(� ������� � ���� 2��� �� �� ���� �� ����(����� ���� ��� 2������ ��2� � ���8��������2�� ���� �� ���� ��� � � � �� �� �� 2�������.�% ���� (8� ��������<��� ����� ��� �� ��� � ���� ���2�� ���� � �� ��� *��� ��.� 0����� (� ���� ��� *������ �8� ���� ����� � �.�� ���� E�� 8������ ������ �� ��.� ��������� ���� �����2���� ������ � ��3� ��������� �� �� � �������� �.� ���8��� � ���������� � �� � ���� ��� ������ � �� � � �� (�����;�� � �� (������ ��� �� ��� � ���� �� ���� � ���� � �� �� � �� �� � �� �� ��� *������ �8� ��������.� ���.��.� � �� ��� �� ���� �� � ��.� ��8� ��� ������9��(�)4&1�3� ���� ��� ������� ��� � ����(� ���*������ �����#������ � )4&1��

���� *������ �� � ���� �� �� 3 � ���%� (� 3� �� =��������.� ��� ������� �@8� ��� ��� �� �� �� ��2��� ��������� �$���2��� ��3������ ��� �� ��� 2� ������.� � ������� �� ��� ���� � �8�� �� ����.��� ��� �� /)&8444� . ��� �;�� �� ��� � �� �����8� ���� �� 5)4%������ ���� . ���� �� ���.� .� �.�� 3� �� ��� ���� � ���� &4� ������� �� 2�� . ����� � ���� *������ �� ��� 3�� ����� � ��� ����� � �.�� ������ (8� ���.� � ��H�� .������ ���� �� ��8����� ��� ������ �� ������;�� ��� �.���� �������*������2��� ������ ���������.���� �� ����������� (����� ��� 2�������������� ����� ����������� � ���. ������ ���2��8� ��� ������� � �� � ��� �� ��� �� � � ��2��� ���� �� ��� � ����� �� ��2���� 3 � � �.�� ��2��� � � ��� �� �� �(� �� ����� ��� �� � ������ ���� � ����� ��� ������3������� �� �� ��� � ������ ����� � �� ���*������ �� �� �� ��� �����.� �� ���*������ �������������� ��� ������ ������� ��� ����������3� ���� ��������� �� �;�� ��.���.��� ����� ���� �� ��(������������� � � ����� � ������������� �� ���� � ���� � �� ��� ��� �� �� �� ��2��� ��� � � ��� �� ����� ��� �� � ��� *������ �� 3���� ���� � ��� ��� ���� � �� �� &57� ����8� � �� ����� ��1)�� �2� ������� ��� �$����������11���� ���� �������=1:� �� ���11���� ���� �������� ��

Research Child and maternal health research programs are undertaken through the Stanford School of Medicine whose faculty members are nationally recognized in the areas of basic science, translational research and clinical pediatric and obstetric research. The strategic priority of the Stanford School of Medicine with respect to research is to promote the development of those interdisciplinary research collaborations most likely to lead to improved patient care and health outcomes through the exploitation of new knowledge of biosciences and disease mechanisms. Interdisciplinary pediatric and obstetric research programs relate to medical, surgical, pathology, radiology and cardiovascular departments within the Stanford School of Medicine. The priority research programs in pediatrics and obstetrics include prevention of preterm births, cancer biology, neuro-oncology, regenerative medicine and developmental biology, molecular and cellular imaging, developmental immunology, definitive molecular and gene therapies and molecular cardiology. The fulfillment of this research mission depends in part on LPCH’s continued delivery of highly specialized care through its Centers of Excellence. LPCH and the Stanford School of Medicine established the Child Health Research Institute (“CHRI’”), an initiative funded by philanthropy and grants whose goal is to facilitate advancement in child and maternal health research at LPCH and the Stanford School of Medicine. CHRI also aims to foster research by utilizing the innovations and technologies being developed by faculty at the Stanford School of Medicine as well as the other University schools. The Chair of the Board of LPCH and the Chief Executive Officer of LPCH represent LPCH on the CHRI Governing Board, which sets the strategic priorities for CHRI. The CHRI Governing Board also has authority to make all decisions regarding the use of philanthropic donations for CHRI, in accordance with the donor’s wishes. See “OPERATING AND FINANCIAL INFORMATION—Related Party Transactions—Transactions with the University” herein. THE PROJECT The Existing Facility was designed in the 1980s to accommodate low-acuity pediatric patients from the local community. It was also envisioned that LPCH would rely on SHC for the provision of substantially all support services. Over time, LPCH developed into an institution that provides high- acuity, specialized pediatric care. The redevelopment of the Existing Facility and the Expansion, undertaken through the Project, is intended to bring the facilities to a level commensurate with LPCH’s current role as a regional, national and international referral center for tertiary and quaternary pediatric care. Substantial completion of construction of the Expansion, excluding imaging components and operating rooms, occurred in July 2017 with patients expected to occupy the Expansion in December 2017. The Expansion consists of two six-story towers (excluding the basements), an acute care pavilion and an ICU pavilion which are located over a diagnostic and treatment platform, comprising a total of 521,000 gross square feet of space, and a 420-space underground parking garage with an additional 10 spaces above ground. The Expansion allows LPCH to increase storage capacity, diagnostic/surgical procedure rooms, inpatient bed count and square footage per bed. Each pavilion has been designed to house ancillary support services and amenities for families at the ground floor level, the public concourse on the first level and patient beds on levels two through five. It is currently anticipated that the Heart Center inpatient beds will be relocated to the second floor of the Expansion upon the opening of the Expansion. A special room for children and their families with certain cancers requiring high dose isotopes therapy has been incorporated into the bed plans on the fourth floor of the acute care pavilion. It is anticipated that the Expansion will result in the addition of 149 beds, comprised of 72 private pediatric ICU beds and 77 acute care beds (73 of the 77 acute care beds are A-24
