���� *������ �� ��� ����.���� � �������� 2� � ��� ��2� ���� ���(� ��� �������� ������ ��� � ���� *������ �� ���� ��� �� � ���(� ��� ��� 3� �� ���������� 2���� �������� 3��� ��� � ����� � �� 38����� �������� � ���� ��� ���� ��� ���� 2����� .(��� � �������� ������ ����� ��� �� � ���*������ ������.�� 3���� ���� � ��� :AN� �����3� � � ���.�� ���� ����� ��� � ��� ����� � ��� ���� ���� 64N� ����� �� ���� ��� .(� � ����� � �� ������������������ ���<���� ��� ������� ��� �.� �������� � ����(8� ���*������ ������������� 3���� � ����� �.��� � �� ���3�������� .(��

����������� � ����� ��� � ���� E�� �3� ������ ���� �� ����� (� ����� ��� �= ���>�� (?@���� 9��(� )4&&� ���� � ��� � ��� �� �� /&%(�� � ��2�� ���� � �. ����� � � � ��� � �� ������2�� ���3��� ���� ��������� � �� ������ ���� � � ����8� ���� ���� ��� � ��� �� ��� �� �� ,��������� � ������ �� � ����� �� � �� ������3�� ��� ���< ��� �� ���$��2� �� (������������. �� �� ��� �� � ������ 2����� � ���� E�� � � �� �� � ���

#� ������ � �� �� � �� ������ ��2�� ����� ����� ��� � ����#� � � ��� 2��� �� ��� ��� ���� ��� �������(��� ��<���3� �� ������ 2���� �� �� � ���������������������� ����2�������#���� 2���� � ������2������ ���� �� �� ���� E�� �������.��� ���� � �� �� � ���� E�� ����#�"�� �� �� � ���

������ � �8��������(������ ������� �� ���- ���� ������ � �������� ���������� � ��� �� ��� � ��� ��� ���� ���;�� �� ��� � �.% � ��. ���� ������ �� � �� � ��� ��������� ��� 2���� �� � �� ��� �� ��� $��2� �� (���������8���E���� � � ���� ��� ��8�� ��� � �������

����� E�� ����.� 8� �.�����(��� �� ���� ���� ��(�F&�)������ �������(���� ��������������������� �� � � � ��� ������ ��� ��� � ����.��� ��� ���� � .(8� ����.�� �� �8� ���� �� �� � �2�������� (� �� ���� � �� �8��� �.� �� ���� ����� � ���� ��������.�� � ���� E�� ���2��� ���� ��� ��F64&������ �� � �2� ���(�������� � �.�� ������������ �� �2������ �������)44A8�)4&)8�)4&5�����)4&68�. �� ��������� �(� �������� ������ ��� ���- ����� � ��)44A8������� � �(������� � ������������ ������ � �8���� �3� ���� ����� ��� ��� �3� ���� ����2���������� �� � ��F)44������ ����(��������� ��������� � �� �� ���� E�� ��� ���� >��*"�� !'� �!#� 0 !�!� ��� !0�",�� �!C���� � ���� "�2����� 0 �� ��� � � �� �� ����� ���C� � �� � �� :� 0�����.?� �� ���� � � ��� �� � �� 3� �� ����� � � ��� . �� � ������� �(� ��� ����� ����� � ��� ��� - ��� �� � �� )44A�� � ,���.���� � �����2��� �� � ����� � � ���8� .� �� � 3� �� ��� � ������� �� ���- ���8�3����������;�� �� ������ ��� �������.�� � �� �� ���� E�� ��

private rooms). The addition of these beds will allow LPCH to address the need for private rooms in the Existing Facility. It is currently planned that the fifth floor bed units in each tower will be shelled at initial occupancy. The design of the fifth floor of each tower is in progress, and each fifth floor will house the inpatient stem cell regenerative medicine and hematology/oncology patients. Special precautions for immune-suppressed and infectious patients will include anterooms and airborne infection isolation in specific patient rooms. Design of the south tower shell space for the first floor outpatient Heart Center, neurodiagnostics and pulmonary lab departments is also in progress. Both the first and fifth floors of each tower are targeted to open in the fall of 2019 and costs are expected to be fully funded by philanthropy. The diagnostic and treatment platform is designed to include technologically advanced surgical suites, post-anesthesia care unit beds, interventional rooms and new rooms for diagnostic imaging equipment, including MRIs, PET MRIs and nuclear medicine. These diagnostic procedure rooms will tie directly into the Hospital’s surgical and imaging platform. The Expansion is designed to include various environmentally sustainable elements. The Expansion is architecturally oriented toward the sun’s movement and allows for natural air flow, and these features are predicted to improve energy performance. It is anticipated that the Expansion design will result in 38% less water usage than used in comparable hospitals and 60% less thermal energy consumption than used in similar sized hospitals in the region. Additionally, the Expansion includes a wind turbine to generate renewable energy. Land use entitlements for the Project were secured from the City of Palo Alto (the “City’’) in July 2011 under the terms of a 51-year development agreement for the comprehensive renewal and replacement of facilities at LPCH, SHC and the Stanford School of Medicine. These entitlements create a new hospital zone on the University campus and grant architectural approvals for the Project construction. Detailed construction plans have been submitted to OSHPD for approval on an incremental basis synchronized with the approved construction schedule. LPCH has received OSHPD approval for all seven increments of the Project. The general contractor for the Project is DPR Construction. In addition, LPCH may use proceeds from the Bonds to fund routine capital expenditures of the Hospital and to acquire the long-term ground lease interest in land and improvements located on the University’s campus, adjacent to the Hospital, for future use. The Project budget, originally set at approximately $1.2 billion likely is to be exceeded because of cost increases related to changes in technology, change orders, and market availability of subcontractors, among other factors. Sources of funding for the Project have consisted of $601 million previously funded through the issuance of revenue bonds in 2008, 2012, 2014 and 2016, grants funded by the Children’s Hospital Bond Act of 2008, philanthropy and internal funds. In addition, a draw on a line of credit with a total available amount of $200 million may be used to fund a portion of the Project. See “OPERATING AND FINANCIAL INFORMATION—Additional Revenue From the State of California—Proposition 3 Funding” herein for information with respect to the grant funded by the Children’s Hospital Bond Act of 2008. Management believes that such sources, together with the proceeds from the Bonds, will be adequate to fund the remaining costs of the Project. A-25

���� ���������� �� �� �� ���� ��� ���� ��� � �E��� � �� 3� �� ��� ���� ��� � �� ���� ��� ���������� � � ���� �� �� ����� � � ��� ������� (�� �� ��������.�� � :&8� )4&/� ���� )4&68� .� �� �3� �� ��� ��� ��� � ������� ���� �� ���� ��.���� �� � �8����������������������-� � �������������� � ���� 8�3�������2�� ��������� ����(�� ���3� � � ���� �� �����8����������� ���� �� �� ���

From fiscal year 2014 to fiscal year 2016, LPCH’s total discharges increased by approximately 1.6% and patient days increased by approximately 1.6%. The increase was largely driven by the Johnson Center, the Cancer Center and the Brain Center. Fiscal year 2016 saw an increase in acuity in the stem cell transplant program as well as the orthopedic service line, increasing the CMI for those programs. For the nine months ended May 31, 2017, compared to the nine months ended May 31, 2016, LPCH’s total discharges and patient days decreased by approximately 0.8% and 0.4%, respectively. The Cancer Center and the Johnson Center were the primary drivers for the decreased volume, while cardiovascular surgery and medical specialty patient days grew by approximately 1% and 7%, respectively. The CMI in the orthopedic surgery and hematology/oncology programs grew due to the increased acuity in these services. Financial Data The following table provides revenue and expense information for LPCH for the three fiscal years ended August 31, 2014, 2015 and 2016 and for the nine-month periods ended May 31, 2016 and 2017. The financial information for the two fiscal years ended August 31, 2015 and 2016 has been derived from the audited consolidated financial statements of LPCH included in Appendix B of this Official Statement. The financial information for the fiscal year ended August 31, 2014 has been derived from audited financial statements of LPCH not included in this Official Statement. The financial information for the nine-month periods ended May 31, 2016 and 2017 has been compiled by the management of LPCH and includes adjustments that management considers necessary to present such information in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States and in a manner consistent with the audited consolidated financial statements for the years ended August 31, 2015 and 2016. The results of operations for the nine-month period ended May 31, 2017 are not necessarily indicative of the results that may be expected for any other interim period or for the full fiscal year. The financial results of PCHA are consolidated with those of LPCH for the fiscal years ended August 31, 2015 and 2016 and for the nine-month periods ended May 31, 2016 and 2017. In management’s view, the assets, liabilities and results of operations and changes in net assets and revenues of PCHA are not material to LPCH. As of and for the fiscal year ended August 31, 2016, PCHA represented less than 1% of LPCH’s consolidated net assets and approximately 6% of LPCH’s consolidated revenues. LPCH became the sole member of LPFCH as of September 1, 2016. The financial results of LPFCH are consolidated with those of LPCH for the nine-month period ended May 31, 2017. In management’s view, the assets, liabilities and results of operations and changes in net assets and revenues of LPFCH are not material to LPCH. As of and for the nine-month period ended May 31, 2017, LPFCH represented approximately 5% of LPCH’s consolidated net assets and approximately 1% of LPCH’s consolidated revenues. Neither PCHA nor LPFCH is a Member of the Obligated Group or otherwise obligated with respect to the Bonds. The financial data should be read in conjunction with the audited consolidated financial statements of LPCH for the fiscal years ended August 31, 2015 and 2016, together with the related notes and the consolidating information, included in Appendix B to this Official Statement, which have been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, independent accountants. A-27

HMOs/PPOs. ����� � � �� �� 3� �� ���� ��E � ���� �� ������ .���<��� ���� �� � ��.� ��� � �� � ��� (��� 2����� ���������� �� 3��.� ������� ��� �� �����2������.����� ����(� ��� ������3� �� ���

Sources of Patient Service Revenue General. In fiscal year 2016, approximately 53% of LPCH’s gross patient service revenues were from commercial payers, including health maintenance organizations (“HMOs”) and preferred provider organizations (“PPOs”) and approximately 41% were from Medi-Cal payer sources. LPCH contracts with all major managed care organizations in its primary and secondary service areas. Approximately 79% of LPCH’s gross patient service revenues are derived from inpatient services. The following are summaries of gross and net patient service revenue by payer source for the fiscal years ended August 31, 2014, 2015 and 2016. Gross Patient Service Revenue Fiscal Year Ended August 31, 2014 2015 2016 Commercial/HMO/PPO 52.1% 53.6% 53.3% Medi-Cal 42.8 40.2 41.0 Other?) 5.1 6.2 5.7 Total 100.0% 100.0% 100.0% Net Patient Service Revenue Fiscal Year Ended August 31, 2014 2015 2016 Commercial /HMO/PPO 79.0% 75.3% 73.8% Medi-Cal 17.2 20.6 19.9 Other?) 3.8 4.1 6.3 Total 100.0% 100.0% 100.0% ( — Tncludes out-of-state Medicaid, Medicare/CHAMPUS and other payers. °) Includes net revenue from the State Provider Fee Program and additional revenue from Medi-Cal Disproportionate Share program, each described below. Source: LPCH records. Medi-Cal. Effective July 1, 2013, the State of California changed its payment mechanism for inpatient services provided to Fee-for-Service (“FFS”) Medi-Cal patients from per-diems to All-Patient Refined Diagnosis Related Group (““APR-DRG”) methodology. Outpatient services to FFS patients continue to be paid on the Medi-Cal fee schedule. Services to managed Medi-Cal patients are provided through contracts with Medi-Cal county-based and commercial managed care organizations. See “BONDHOLDERS’ RISKS—Patient Service Revenues—Medi-Cal Program” and “BONDHOLDERS’ RISKS—Patient Service Revenues—Medi-Cal Managed Care” in the forepart of this Official Statement. LPCH’s major managed Medi-Cal contracts include: the Health Plan of San Mateo, Anthem Blue Cross, Central California Alliance for Health and the Santa Clara Family Health Plan, to provide inpatient and outpatient care. Outpatient care for all four plans is reimbursed on a multiple tied to the standard Medi-Cal fee schedule. Inpatient care is reimbursed on a per diem basis, which varies according to the terms of LPCH’s contract with each of these plans. The exception is Health Plan of San Mateo which was transitioned to APR-DRG reimbursement effective November 2016. HMOs/PPOs. PCH contracts with all major health plans organized and operating in its primary service area. The following table sets forth the five managed care payers for LPCH with the A-29

Disproportionate Share Hospital (“DSH”) Funding�� � ����� � . ��� � 2����� ��������� ��� ��(��� �� �� ��� ������ ����� ��.����,����� ������,�������� �� � �� ������� � � �� ��(����� �� ���� ����� � �� � 3� ��� ��8� ������ ��� ���� ,����� �� � ,�������� �� ��� �� � ��� ��� � �� � � ��� ������ � �2� ��� ��� ���� �� ���� �#���� � � ���� �����.������ ��� ����������.8��� 3������ �����<� � �� �>#��� ��������� ?� ������� �0�����.� ���� 2����������� ����� ��� �����2��.��� � ������.����� (�� � � ��� � ��� (�� ��� � � � ���������.�(�� ������ �����(8���������� ����2���#��� ��������� �������� �,���%���� �� ��� ��� �� ���� � ���8���������.�F7�5������ ������������(�� �)4&:������������� �;�����(�� �#��� ������.�����������(�� ��)4&58�)4&/�����)4&6����

Provider Fee Program�������� � �� ������� �������� ���� � ���������(�-����&:A:����)4478���� ���������(�� � ���������(�-���� &6/:� ���)4&48�3����� �� ������������ ��� ���J���� (����� �����0��� =>J�0?@� � . ��� ���� �� � ��� ��� 0��� � . ��� =� ���� �2��(8� ��� >� 2��� � 0��� � . ��?@��� ���� � 2��� �0���� . ������ ������;���� (����� ��������� ���� ��������� ����.��� ������ ���� ��� ��� ���� �� 8� � ������� 3� �� ���� ��� �� ����.� �����8� 3 ���� ��� ����� � � 2���� ��������� ��� ��(��� �� � �� ����� ��� ������������ � ���� � ������� � ����� �������� ���� ��� 2� �.��� ������ �����$��� � ��� � 2��� � 0��� � . ��8� � ��� ����� ���� � ��� ���� ����2�� � �� ������.� ��� ��� ������ ,���%���� ��������� ��� ��(��� �� ���� ��� ;���� (� ���� ����� ����� ����8�3����� �� ������ ���� � ��� ���� ����2�� ����� � ��(� ��� ,���%���� ��(��� �� ���� ����� ������ ����� ����� �2�� �� � �� �� ��� ��� ���� � 2��� � 0��� � . ��� 3��� �� ���&8� )447� � �.�� #������ �:&8� )4&4��� �����;��� � ��.���� � �� ��� 3��� � � � ��� ���� � ���� J�0� ���� � ��� ��� 0��� � . ���8� ��� �� �� � �� 3����� 3��� �� ��������� �(� ��� ,���%���� � ��� ���"����� ����� � �� 2���� ��� � �� )4&:� ����3��� ��� ����� � � �� 9���� (�&8� )4&5� � �.�� #������ � :&8� )4&6��� � �� #������ � )4&58� ��� ��� � �� � �,����� �� O�,�������� �� 2����� =>�,�?@� ��� 2��� ��� ���%� %�� 2���� ,���%���� ��������� � ��(��� �� � � �� �� ���� �� (%� � �� �� ���� ���� �,����� 2���� �� ���������� ��� ���� � ������� �%������� ��� ���� � ��� � �� �� ����� � � ��� � �

largest volume, listed with the percentage of gross patient service revenue that each represents for the fiscal year ended August 31, 2016: Fiscal Year Ended August 31, 2016 Payer Percent of Gross Revenues Anthem Blue Cross 17.7% Blue Shield 7.2% UnitedHealthcare 7.0% Aetna 6.0% Cigna 4.6% Source: LPCH records. LPCH participates in most types of health plan products, including PPO, Point of Service (“POS”), Exclusive Provider Organization (“EPO”) and traditional indemnity plans. These agreements include rates for obstetrics, pediatrics and transplant services. LPCH does not accept payment on the basis of capitation with commercial payers. LPCH’s current agreement with Anthem Blue Cross is effective through August 31, 2019. LPCH’s agreements with Blue Shield of California and Aetna are effective through April 30, 2018 and August 31, 2018, respectively; accordingly, these agreements are slated for renegotiation in 2018. Additional Revenue From the State of California Disproportionate Share Hospital (“DSH”) Funding. This program provides supplemental payments to hospitals participating in Medicare and Medicaid that treat a disproportionately substantial number of low income, uninsured and Medicare or Medicaid patients compared to other hospitals. Private hospitals that meet DSH criteria are eligible for certain funding, known as stabilization or “DSH replacement” funds. Funding is provided based on a hospital having met the eligibility criteria three years prior to the funding year. Historically, LPCH has received DSH replacement funds for Medi-Cal patients from time to time, including $9.4 million in fiscal year 2013. LPCH did not qualify for DSH funding in fiscal years 2014, 2015 and 2016. Provider Fee Program. The State of California enacted State Assembly Bill 1383 in 2009, as amended by State Assembly Bill 1653 in 2010, which established a Hospital Quality Assurance Fee (“QAF”) Program and a Hospital Fee Program (collectively, the “Provider Fee Program’). The Provider Fee Program imposed a quality assurance fee on certain California general acute care hospitals that, combined with federal matching funds, would be used to provide supplemental payments to certain hospitals and support the State’s effort to maintain health care coverage for children. Under the Provider Fee Program, some California hospitals receive more funding in increased Medi-Cal supplemental payments than the quality assurance fees paid, while other California hospitals receive less money in Medi-Cal payments than fees paid. The effective period of the initial Provider Fee Program was April 1, 2009 through December 31, 2010. Subsequent legislation allowed for three additional QAF and Hospital Fee Programs, the latest of which was established by the Medi-Cal Hospital Reimbursement Improvement Act of 2013 and was in effect from January 1, 2014 through December 31, 2016. In December 2014, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (“CMS”) approved the fee-for-service Medi-Cal supplement payments portion of this thirty-month extension. CMS approved both the expansion population and non-expansion population portion of the first of four A-30

Transactions with the University�� � ����� �� ��� �� � ��.� �������� � �;�� (� ����� �� � ��� �� �� � ����� � ���3� �� ���$��2� �� (�� �������� ��������� 2������ �� ���$��2� �� (���������.� ���� ������� � ��8� ���� � � �8��� ����� ��� ���8� �� 8� ��.��8� ���� �� � �������� �� �� � �� ���� ����(� ������ � ����� �� 2������� ������� � �� ���$��2� �� (�3� ����� ���� ��(�F):�:������ ������F)A�:� ����� ��� � ����������(�� ����������.�� �:&8�)4&6�������.�� �:&8�)4&/8� ����� �2��(8������ �� �� ���� ��� � ����� ���� �� 2����8� �� ������� �� 2����8� ���� �� � ��������� ��� ��� � �� ���� ��� � � ���� �� �� �� � � ��� ���� ����.��� ��� �� � ���� �� � � � ��� ������� (�� �� � ��� � �� (� ���� �;������ 8� �� 8� ��� ��� � �� ���� ��������������� �������������� ������� ���� �� ���� �������������� � ���� �� �������� ������ �� � �������������-��

���� ��� �� 2� ���� � �� ���$��2� �� (� ��������.� �� � ���� �� ���� ���� (� ���� ������ ��3� �� ��� ���� ��(�F:�/������ ������F:�)������ ��� � ����������(�� ����������.�� �:&8�)4&6�������.�� �:&8� )4&/8� ����� �2��(�������������� 2������� �������� �� ���$��2� �� (�� ������ ��������>� ����� � ���3� �� ���� ��� ����� �� ��,�������?���� 3��

Transactions with the Stanford School of Medicine����� 2������� �������� �� ���$��2� �� (� ���8� �����������(8� ��� � ��� �� ��� �� �� ,�������8� �������� ��������� �� 2����� �� � ������ � ����8� ��������.� � ��� ��%������ ��(�������8��������� �� �� � �8� �� �� � ��� �8� ������������ ��� � (� �� 2������� ��(��� �� � ������� 2�������������� ������.���� ������ ��� ��� �� ���� �� �2������������� ���� �&8� )4468� ����� ���� ��� $��2� �� (� �� � ��� �� � �� � ����� ���� �� 2����� �. ����� � =>���?@� 3����� ����.���� � ����� ��� �.� � � ����� ���� � ���� � ���� �2����� ��� ��� � ����� ��� ���� �� � ��� ���������

potential managed care supplemental payments of this thirty-month program in April 2016 and June 2015, respectively. The California Medi-Cal Hospital Reimbursement Initiative also known as Proposition 52, approved by California voters in November 2016, will extend the Provider Fee Program indefinitely and put protections in place to prevent diversion of funds from the program. LPCH participates in the Provider Fee Program and pays both the QAF and the California Health Foundation and Trust pledge, which are recorded in other expenses. LPCH receives supplemental payments from both DHCS and the managed care plans, which are recorded in net patient service revenue. Provider Fee Program revenue is recognized when CMS approves the relevant portion of Medi-Cal supplemental payments to the State. For the years ended August 31, 2016, 2015 and 2014, LPCH recognized $51.8, $79.8 million, and $14.6 million, respectively, in net patient service revenue for Medi-Cal fee-for-service and managed care supplemental payments and $24.2, $43.1 million and $5.3 million, respectively, in other operating expense, which are included in LPCH’s consolidated statement of operations and changes in net assets for quality assurance fees paid to California Department of Health Care Services. Proposition 3 Funding. Proposition 3, known as the Children’s Hospital Bond Act of 2008, was an initiative enacted by California voters. This Act authorized the issuance of $980 million in bonds, to be repaid from the State’s General Fund, to support construction projects of children’s hospitals. In August 2013, LPCH received $97.4 million (less costs of issuance and administrative costs), which was applied to the costs of the Project. Related Party Transactions LPCH is party to several agreements, arrangements and transactions with SHC, the Stanford School of Medicine and other entities related to the University relating to the provision of services to the patients of LPCH. Transactions with the University. LPCH records operating expense or equity transfers to account for transactions with the University. LPCH purchases services from the University including telecommunications, transportation, certain utilities, rent, legal, and internal audit. Costs incurred by LPCH for these services purchased from the University were approximately $23.3 million and $28.3 million for the fiscal years ended August 31, 2016 and August 31, 2015, respectively, and are recorded as professional services, purchased services, and other expenses in the consolidated statements of operations and changes in net assets for those fiscal years or as property and equipment, net, in the consolidated balance sheets included in the audited consolidated financial statements of LPCH attached hereto as Appendix B. The total recoveries from the University including rent and certain salary and benefits were approximately $3.5 million and $3.2 million for the fiscal years ended August 31, 2016 and August 31, 2015, respectively. Clinical services purchased from the University are described in “Transactions with the Stanford School of Medicine” below. Transactions with the Stanford School of Medicine. Services purchased from the University and, specifically, the Stanford School of Medicine, include clinical services that benefit LPCH, including hospital-based physicians, medical direction, blood products, and medical library services. Payment for these services is based on management’s best estimate of market value. On September 1, 2006, LPCH and the University entered into a Professional Services Agreement (“PSA”) which assigned to LPCH the right to bill and collect all revenue related to pediatric and obstetric clinical A-31

Transactions with SHC�� � ����� ���� ���� ��� �� �� ���� ���� � ��8� ��������.� 2� � ��� ��� �� � �� �(� ���8� ������ �� � ���8� ����.��� �� �� � � �� ��.8� ���� �� � ����� ����.���� �� � ���� � � ��� � �������� ����� 2����8�3������ ���������������� ��������� 2�������� ���� �� ���� ���� � ���� �� �� �� � � �����������.�������� ����� �8�� ����� �� ����� 3����������������������� ������.���� ��� ��� � �� ��� ���� � ������� ��� � � � � � ��� ��� �� 2����� 3��� ��� ���� ��(� F:4�5� ����� �� ���� F)A�6� ����� ��� � ����������(�� ����������.�� �:&8�)4&6�����)4&/8� ����� �2��(��

����� ��� � �� ������� 2� � ��� �� 2����� � �� ����� � ������ �� 2����� �������� �� � ��.� �8� �� ������� �� � �<� � �8��� � 2�� � ���� ��� � .(8� ���� � �� �� � .(8�������� � (�������� � � �� ����� �� 2����8� 3����� ��� ��������� ��� �� ������� �� 2����� ��� ��� � �� ���� ��� � � ���� �� �� �� � � ��� ���� ����.��� ��� �� � ���� �8� ��� ��� .��� ����� � ����� ������ �� �� �� ��� �.�� �� ��� .��� �� ������ � ��� ���� ��� � �� ���� � ��� �� ���� ��� �������� ���� � � � � �� 2������� ������� � ������3��� ��� ���� ��(�F51�)������ ������F51�&������ �� � � ��� �������(�� ����������.�� �:&8�)4&6�����)4&/8� ����� �2��(��

������ � �� � ����� 2��������� ������� 2�8�������� ��������� 2����� � ������ �� � �������� �� 2����� � 2����� �(� �� � ��� ���� ������ �8� ���� ������� ���� �� ���� �� � ��.� ��������8� ��������.� � ��� ������������ ���� E�� ������������ 2����� �������� ���� ��(�F::�5������ ������F:4�&������ ��� � ����������(�� ����������.�� �:&8�)4&6�����)4&/8� ����� �2��(8������ ���������������� ��������� 2����� ���� �� ������������� ���� �� ���� ���� � ���� �� �� �� � � �����������.�������� ����� �� ����� �� (� �����;������ 8��� 8���� ���� �� ���� ��������������� �� ��������

Transactions with LPFCH�����0��� �� � ������ ����������2������ �����.��� � (�� ���������� ������������� ������ �� � ���� . ���� �� ���� ��� ����� �� ��,��������� ������� ���� �&8�)4&68� ��0���� �2� ���� ��� � � ��� � ���� ����� �� �� �� � � � ��3� � � ������ �� � ���3� ������� ��� � �� � ��� ����� �� � ��0��� ���� (�� ��� ���� ��(� 6A� ����% ���� �;��2���� � ���� (���� ��2 ��� � ���� �����.� �� �2� ���8� ��������.� � ���� � �� .�� �8� � �2� �� . �� �8� � � � �� .�� �8���E � .�� �8� �������� .�� �������������.�� ����������� ��� �� � �����&7768���0������� ������� �� ����F&�6������ ��� ������ ���� ������������� ��� . ���� �� ���� ��� ����� �� ��,�������8���������.��� �� ��F)41������ ����� �������(�� �)4&6��

������ � �� �� ���� ��.������� �� � �����������.���� ���������� ������������� ��� . ���� �� ���� ��� ����� �� ��,�������8���0���� ���� ��� ���3 �� �� ��2��� ������� ���� �� � � ���� �2��(� ��2�� � �� ���� &8444� ����� �� � �.� � � ��� ���� 0 ������ � -�(� � ���� � ���� ������� ���� ���� ��� � ����2������ ����� �� � � ��� �� ��� �2� �.�� �� F&� ����� �� �������(� �� � ��� �� �� ��� 3� �� ��������� � . ������������.���� ������ ����� ��� �������

����� �� ������� ���� �����.� �� 2����� � 2����� �(� ��0��� ���� �� ��� ��� �������� ��� ���� �����.�������>0$!#"� � !'?��� �����

services on behalf of the Stanford School of Medicine faculty. In return, LPCH reimburses the University for the services provided by the physician faculty. The PSA is revised periodically, most recently as of September 1, 2016. The expense recorded related to payments and accruals for all of these services amounted to approximately $209.1 million and $188.9 million for the fiscal years ended August 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. The collections received from external parties by LPCH as agent on behalf of the School of Medicine were recorded in other revenue and purchased services. The amounts were $16.7 million and $12.7 million as of August 31, 2016 and August 31, 2015, respectively. Transactions with SHC. LPCH and SHC share certain functions, including various information systems, human resources, managed care contracting, and materials management. The costs for these shared services, which are included in purchased services in the consolidated statements of operations and changes in net assets, are allocated between SHC and LPCH based on management’s best estimates. LPCH’s total cost for shared services was approximately $30.4 million and $28.6 million for the fiscal years ended August 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. LPCH also purchases various services from SHC. These services include operating room, cardiac catheterization, interventional radiology, radiation oncology, and laboratory. The cost of these services, which is included in purchased services in the consolidated statements of operations and changes in net assets, is charged back to LPCH based on a percentage of charges intended to approximate costs or a cost per procedure. LPCH’s total cost for services purchased from SHC was approximately $47.2 million and $47.1 million for the fiscal years ended August 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively. In addition to the services described above, LPCH purchases services from SHC that include services provided by interns and residents, maintenance and certain operating expenses, including utilities and capital projects. These services totaled approximately $33.4 million and $30.1 million for the fiscal years ended August 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively, and are included in purchased services and other expenses in the consolidated statements of operations and changes in net assets or in property and equipment, net, in the consolidated balance sheets of LPCH. Transactions with LPFCH. LPFCH operates as the exclusive fundraising entity for LPCH and the child health and obstetric programs of the Stanford School of Medicine. On September 1, 2016, LPFCH converted its corporate status from a nonprofit corporation without members to one with LPCH as its sole member. LPFCH employs approximately 68 full-time equivalent employees devoted to fundraising activities, including foundation gifts, private grants, corporate gifts, major gifts, planned gifts and annual gifts. Since its creation in 1996, LPFCH has raised more than $1.6 billion for LPCH and the child health programs of the Stanford School of Medicine, including a record $207 million in fiscal year 2016. In addition to soliciting cash donations and pledges for LPCH and the child health programs of the Stanford School of Medicine, LPFCH coordinates the work of seven auxiliaries that collectively have more than 1,000 members throughout the San Francisco Bay Area. The auxiliaries and their individual members contribute an average of $1 million annually that is directed toward specific programs including uncompensated care at LPCH. LPCH purchases fundraising services provided by LPFCH and records the expense as fundraising. See “FUNDRAISING” herein. A-32

Patient Service Revenues���������� �2���/:�:N8�5&�4N�����/�1N� ��� ��. ����� ��� � �2������ ��� ������� (�� � )4&6� � �� � ��� ����� ���� � �� ���� ����.��� �� �� �����8� ,���%���� ���� �� � ��(� �8� ����� �2��(�� � ���� >��*"�� !'� �!#� 0 !�!� ��� !0�",�� �!L� � ���� �� �� ��� � �� 2���� "�2�����?� � "�2������ � �� �� ���� �� ��.� ��� �� � �� ��� ���� �� �� �� �� 2����� � �� � 2����� ���� � �� �� ���� � ����� ��� ����� � ����<������� �� �I�� 3�2� 8� ���� ������ (������� �� � ���� � � � � � �� � ��� � �� ������ �.��� � ���� ���� ���� ������E�� ��� �� � ������� ��� �����*� ��� ��� ��� � �� ���� ����� � ��� ���� � ����.��� �� �� ���� �� ������ � �� ������ �� �� ��(��� � � ��� ���������� ��� ��� ��� ��� � � �� �����. ����� �������� ������(��� � � ����������� ��� ��� ����� ����� ��� �� ��� ������� ���� ��(� %�������������������� �� �� ���������� �� ������ ���� �� � ���2�������� �.� ���.�����.���� ��� �� � � � � � �� �� ��� ����������� ��3�8� �.��� � ��8� � � �� � � ��� ���� ���� � �� ���� ��(��� � � ����� ,���.���� � �2��3�� ���� � �� ��������� � ����� ��� � ��� ����� �� ����� �������� � � ������.��� �������.��� �� �� � � �� ���� � ��� �� � ���� � � �� � � �� � ���. �� � ��� ���� ���3���8� ��� 3���� ��� ����.��������3������ �.��� � ����

Provision for Doubtful Accounts�� ������ ���� � �� �� � � �����.� ����2������� �� �� �%�� (� ��(� �������� ��� ������������� ��� (�� � ��� ��������������� � ����� �� �� �� � ��.��� � ������������ �� �� � �� ���� 2��� ��� �� �� ������� �� ������������� ������.���� ������������ � ������� ����� � � ���� � ��8� ������ �� ��� ����� ���� ������ ���� �� � � ���� � �� ������ ��� � ,���.���� � ������ �� �� ������ �2��3�� ����� ������ ���� � �������3 � �% ��������2� �������.��������������� ������ �� � � ��8� ��(� ����8��� � ����� ��� � ��� �������.�� �. 2� ���� ������� ���� ��� . ����� ��������� �������� � ���� � �� ����� �� �� ����2����8�������� 3����� �� � � ����

Risk Management�� � ����� ����%���� ��� � � � ����� ���� ���� .��� ��� ������� (� ����8� 3 �� ��� � ������ � �� ���� �� � � �� �� ���� (��� �������� ���� � � � � ���� � �������8� ��� ���� ����� ��� 3��� ������ ������� ���� � �� ����� ��� ��� ����%���� ����� ��� 2��� �� ��� �������� ���� �� � 0 � ��� �� � �� �� � � ����������� ��������� ����� ������ 2� �.��� �� �� �%�� (����� � �8�����>���*"� !0�",�� �!C ��� ����?��� �����

�� � ����� ��������'��� ���������� (�L�������������%���� ��� � �.���$, �� ��� ������ ����(� � ��� =>�$, �?@8� �� ��� �2�� ���� � � �� � ��� E �� �(� � � ����� �(������ �������8� � ��������� ���� �� ��������.��� ��� ������� (� � ��������� �������%������ 2� �.����$, �� ��� � ���>�?��(� ��,��-�� ��0 ��������� �� 2� ����(��$, �8���������� ������ ����� ����������� (� ��� 2��� ������ �������� 2� �.��� �� �� �%�� (����� � �8�������� ��������>���*"� !0�",�� �!C ��� ����?��� �����

Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Recent Financial Performance Certain Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates. The preparation of the financial statements of LPCH requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, the reported amounts of revenues and expenses and the disclosure of contingent liabilities. Management bases its estimates on historical experience and various other assumptions that it believes are reasonable and are in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States. Management evaluates its estimates on an ongoing basis and makes changes to the estimates as experience develops or new information becomes available. Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions. The most significant estimates relate to patient accounts receivable allowances and self- insurance reserves. Actual results may differ from those estimates. All amounts set forth in Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Recent Financial Performance have been rounded. Patient Service Revenues. LPCH derived 53.3%, 41.0% and 5.7% of its gross patient revenues in fiscal year 2016 from commercial insurers and managed care plans, Medi-Cal and other payers, respectively. See “OPERATING AND FINANCIAL INFORMATION-Sources of Patient Service Revenue.” Revenues are recorded during the period the health care services are provided and are reported at the estimated net realizable amounts; however, the complexity and extent of interpretation from contracts and regulations could result in adjustments to these estimates. Estimates of contractual deductions under managed care health plans are based upon payment terms specified in the related contractual agreements and actual payment rates. The estimated reimbursement amounts are made on a payer-specific basis and are recorded based on the best information available regarding management’s interpretation of the applicable laws, regulations, contract terms and recent actual payment rates. Management reviews the contractual deductions estimation process to consider and incorporate changes in managed care contractual terms that result from contract renegotiations and renewals, as well as changes in laws and regulations. Provision for Doubtful Accounts. The collection of outstanding receivables from third-party payers and patients is LPCH’s primary source of cash and is critical to its operating performance. The amount of the provision for doubtful accounts is based upon management’s assessment of expected net collections, based on historical experience and other collection indicators. Management relies on detailed reviews of historical collections and write-offs. Adverse changes in business office operations, payer mix, economic conditions or funding for governmental health care programs could affect LPCH’s collection of accounts receivable, cash flow and operations. Risk Management. LPCH self-insures for professional and general liability risks, workers’ compensation and a portion of employee medical and postretirement medical, as described below. These liabilities are reflected as self-insurance reserves on the balance sheet. For information about excess insurance and reinsurance coverage from third-party insurers, see “OTHER INFORMATION— Insurance” herein. e Professional and General Liability - LPCH is self-insured through SUMIT Insurance Company Ltd. (“SUMIT”), a captive insurer that is jointly controlled by LPCH and SHC, for medical malpractice and general liability losses under clatms-made coverage. SUMIT is rated “A” by A.M. Best. For claims not covered by SUMIT, LPCH maintains professional liability reserves and purchases coverage from third-party insurers, as described in “OTHER INFORMATION— Insurance” herein. A-33

� ��� �� � ��.� ��������� ��� ������F71�)������ �8� � 7�1N8� �� � �� 2� � �� � ��� � ���� ���� ���� ���� (��������� ��� � ��������� � ���������,�(�:&8�)4&18���� �������(�F66�&������ �8� �&/�/N8� 2� � ������������%� � ���� � �����)4&6����� ���� ����� � �� ����� �8���������.������� ���������� ���.� 3�.��� ��� � ���� � ��3� ������3�� � �� � �� � ��� �� �3� �� ����� ������� �� ��� ��� ���� 3����� � >���*"� !0�",�� �!C*��� (���?��� ����������. ������ ������� ������ (��� �� �� ��� ����� �����.����� ��� � � ��� � ��� �����.� �� ���*������ �������� �� ����������=��������.���������� �� ���� 2��� �0���� . ��@���� ��������� ����(�F:5�:������ �8� �6�&N8�� ��������(����� ���� ��������� ��(��� �� � ���� ��� ����� �� ��,��������� ��� 2������ 2������(� �����(������������ (���*�������� �� ���� ���� � ��� � 2��� � 0��� � . ��� ��� ��� )4&1� ����%� � �� �� � �� 3� �� F&/�:� ����� �8� ��� � ��� ��� �F&A�/������ ��� � ������������%� � ���� � �����)4&6��

� ������� ����� �������(�F)65�:������ �8� �A�5N8�� ����.�� �:&8�)4&6� �,�(�:&8�)4&1������ ������� ����8�F&A1�5������ ��3��� ��� ���� � �� ���� �� ���� � �� ����0��8�3�����3�������� �2����� �� ��� ���� �&8�)4&6����� �� ����� ����� �������(�F)4&�5������ �8�3�����3���� ��� ��(����� ����.�� �� ����� ������ ��� �. ��.�� �� �� � ��� � �� ��� ��� � ���� E�� 8�3����� ������ ���������� �� �������� ���� ��F1&�5������ �� ��������(����� ���0������� �����.� ��������� �� ���� ��� ����� �� ��,���������� �2�� ��� �� ��� ������ F6A�:� ����� �8� � �� ��.�� � :&8� )4&6� � ,�(� :&8� )4&18� 3����� 3��� �����(� � ��� ����� � ���� �� ���� � �� ����0������ ����� ����� ����� �������(�F)44�:������ �8� �7�&N8�� �� ��.�� � :&8� )4&6� �,�(� :&8� )4&18� ����� ��.� ��� ����� � �� � �� ���� ��.� ��0��� ���� ��� ��� � ��

e Post-Retirement Medical Benefits — Liabilities for post-retirement medical claims for current and retired employees are actuarially determined by Mercer Consulting. e Self-Funded Medical — Liabilities for health claims for current employees are actuarially determined by Mercer Consulting. e Workers’ Compensation — LPCH, jointly with SHC, purchases insurance for workers’ compensation claims with a $750,000 deductible per occurrence and $20.5 million annual aggregate. An actuarial estimate of retained losses (or losses retained within the deductible) has been used to record a liability. Historical Performance Nine Months Ended May 31, 2017. Excess of revenue over expenses was $24.0 million for the nine months ended May 31, 2017, as compared to $25.3 million for the nine months ended May 31, 2016. Excluding the impact of the Provider Fee Program, excess of revenues over expenses was a loss of $1.7 million for the nine months ended May 31, 2017 as compared to a gain of $10.1 million for the nine-month period in 2016, principally due to a reduction in certain high-margin cases mostly in the period September 2016 through February 2017 and transition costs in connection with the Project, including the ramp up of employee recruitment and training in preparation for the opening of the Expansion, which were offset by higher investment income. Total operating revenues were $1,083.2 million for the nine months ended May 31, 2017, as compared to $1,028.1 million for the comparable period in 2016, an increase of approximately $55.1 million, or 5.4%. Net patient service revenue (excluding revenue from the Provider Fee Program) increased $43.4 million, or 4.7%, for the nine months ended May 31, 2017, from the same period in 2016, mainly due to increases in outpatient volume and commercial managed care contract rates. Revenue recorded under the Provider Fee Program for the nine months ended May 31, 2017 was $41.0 million, as compared to $33.6 million for the same nine-month period in 2016. Total operating expenses increased $97.2 million, or 9.7%, period over period. Salaries and employee benefits for the nine months ended May 31, 2017, increased by $66.1 million, or 15.5%, over the same nine-month period in 2016 due to a combination of factors, including an increase in nursing wages in connection with a new contract entered into with the nurses union referred to below under “OTHER INFORMATION—Enmpployees” herein and a gradual ramp up of employee recruitment and training in preparation for the opening of the Expansion. All other expenses (excluding expense from the Provider Fee Program) increased in total by $34.3 million, or 6.1%, principally due to increases in payments to the Stanford School of Medicine for services provided by the physician faculty. Expenses recorded under the Provider Fee Program in the 2017 nine-month period were $15.3 million, as compared to $18.5 million for the same nine-month period in 2016. Total assets increased by $264.3 million, or 8.4%, from August 31, 2016 to May 31, 2017. Of this increase, $187.4 million was the result of the consolidation of LPFCH, which was effective as of September 1, 2016. Current assets decreased by $201.4 million, which was primarily due to usage of cash to fund the ongoing construction costs related to the Project, while the increase in current liabilities of $71.4 million is mainly due to LPFCH fundraising on behalf of the Stanford School of Medicine. Investments increased $68.3 million, from August 31, 2016 to May 31, 2017, which was mainly attributable to the consolidation of LPFCH. Total net assets increased by $200.3 million, or 9.1%, from August 31, 2016 to May 31, 2017, reflecting the impact of consolidating LPFCH and income from A-34

*������ �� �2����� 2� � ��������� 3��� ��� ���� ��(� F5A�5� ����� �� ��� ������� (�� � )4&68� ��� � ��� ��� �F&:A�:������ �� ��� �������(�� �)4&/�� ��������� ����� ���������� �2����� 2� ����������3��� � ��� ��(� ���� � �� ��� ����� ��� ��� ��� � �� �� � � ��� =��������.� ��� ����� � �� ��� � 2��� � 0��� � . ��@� ��F/A�)������ ��� ��� ��(������ ���� � �������� ���������� � ������ � ������� ����� � �� �� ��� �����.� �� ��� *������ ��� � �� ���� � �8� �� � ��2�� ��� � ��� ��� ��� ������ �(� F)&�A� ����� �� ���� �� � �2������ 2� ����������� �� ���� 2��� �0���� . ������ �������(�F7�4������ ������ � ��� ����.� �� �,����� 2����� � ���:4�� � ��� . ���� ��)4&5%)4&6������ � ��.���� ���� ��������(�� �)4&6�3��� F:A�6������ ��� ��� ��� �F&4/�A������ ������������(�� �)4&/����

� ��� �� � ��.� �2��������� ������F))�/������ �8� �&�6N8�� ���������(�� �)4&/� ��������(�� � )4&6�� �!� ��� ��� ��� 2���� �2����� ��� ������F:1�:������ ��=��������.� �2������ �� ���� 2��� �0��� � . ��@� � �� ��� ����� �� � �� ��� ������� (�� � )4&/8� �����(� ���� � ��� ������ ����� ����� � � �� � ��� ���������.����� ����(� �8����������� �������� � �� ��� �2��� ����� �� � �2�������� ��������� ��� �� � ���(�F&)�1������ ��� ��������(����� � ������ �������� ����� �� ���� �� �� ���� � ���������

� ��� �� � ��.� ��������� ��� ������ ��� ���� ��(� F&4A�1� ����� �8� � A�AN� ������� (�� � 2� � �������(�� � =��������.��������� ��� ��� � ���� 2��� �0���� . ��@�� ����� ������������ (��������� �� ��� ������ �(� F66�1������ �8� � &)�7N8� � �� ������� (�� � )4&/� � ������� (�� � )4&6� ��� ����� ��.��� � ��� ��������� (��� �� �� ��� ����� �����.����� ��� � � �� �� ��� �����.� �� ���*������ �������� �� � ��������� =��������.� �������� � �� ���� 2��� �0���� . ��@� ��� ������ ��� ��� �(�F5&�7������ �8� � /�7N8�� ��������(����� ���� �����������(��� �� � ���� ��� ����� �� ��,��������� ��� 2������ 2����� �(� �����(������������ (�������.�� ������(�� � �� ���� ��.�� �����.�� ��� � �� ���8���� ���������� � ������ .����������������!�3� � �� ��� ������� ���� �����.���������(2��������� ��'� ����� �� � ��� ��� � ��% ����� � ������������(�� �)4&6���*������� �� �������� � ���� 2��� �0���� . �������������(�� � )4&6�3���F)5�)������ �8����� ��� ��� �F5:�)������ �����)4&/��

������� ��� ���� �� . �3� �(� F)A6�4� ����� �� ��� ������� (�� � )4&68� � &4�4N8� � �2��� �(� �� � ����� � �� �� ����� .��� � ��� � �� �� � � ��8� � �.� ��2�� ��� � ���� ���� �����.� ���� �8� ���� ��� ��2�� ��� � �� .��� � ��� �� � ��.� ������ ��� � �� (� ���� �;������ �� � ����� ���� ����� �;��2���� �� ��� ����������������(�� �)4&6� 2� ��������(�� �)4&/��(�/A�6N8� �F&71�4������ �8����� ���� ����� � �� �� � ������ � �� ���)4&6��� ����-�- ���� � �������3� ����������3� �� �3���� � �� ���,� .���� �8� �� ����(� ���� ��(�� �� �� � ����������� ��� ��� � ���� E�� ����� �� ����� ����� ������F))/�7������ �8� � :5�)N8� ���� �� �� � ������� ���� ��� ������F)&�)������ �8� � A�1N�� �B� ���� �� �� � ���� �8� �� � �� ��� � ��� �� � ����2������ ��� ������ �(� F:�6������ �� � F)6A�)������ �8� � ��� ��(� ���� � ��� 2���� �� ��� �2������(������!� �� �� (������;������ ���� ����������������(�� �)4&6��(�F:/&�4������ �8� �:)�6N8� ��� � ��� ��� � ������� (�� � )4&/8� �����(� ���� � ��� � �� �� � �� �� ��� � E�� � ���� ��3� � �� ��� � ������ ���� ��� ����(2���� ����� ��'� ��� �!� � ���� �� ��� ������ F&/1�)������ �� ��� ������� (�� � )4&6� 2� � �������(�� �)4&/��

����� �� 3��.� �����3���� ��� ����(�����.���� � ������������ ���� ����� ������ 2� �.�� �� ������������������ ��� 2���� ������� �.% � ������� ������� �������� � ��� � ����������(�� �������� ��.�� � :&8� )4&58� )4&/� ���� )4&6� ���� � � � ��� ��� � �� 2���� � 2� �.�� � ������ � � ��� ������� (�� � ��������.�� �:&8�)4&68���E�� ��� � ����� � ������������ �� ���- ������ �� ����2��������� ���� ��� 2���� ���������� ��������� ������3� �� ���� 2���� � �;�� ���� �� �� ���,�� � � ���� � ���

investments in the hereinafter defined Merged Pool and fundraising results, as offset by the loss from operations and equity transfers to related parties. Fiscal Year Ended August 31, 2016 Compared to Fiscal Year Ended August 31, 2015. Excess of revenue over expenses was approximately $48.4 million in fiscal year 2016, as compared to $138.3 million in fiscal year 2015. This decrease in excess revenue over expenses was primarily due to a decrease in income from operations (excluding the impact of the Provider Fee Program) of $58.2 million primarily as a result of an increase in personnel costs in anticipation of the opening of the Expansion. In addition, net investment income decreased by $21.8 million and net revenues over expenses from the Provider Fee Program decreased by $9.0 million due to the timing of CMS approvals for the 30 month program from 2014-2016. Operating income for fiscal year 2016 was $38.6 million compared to $105.8 million in fiscal year 2015. Total operating revenues increased $22.5 million, or 1.6%, from fiscal year 2015 to fiscal year 2016. Net patient service revenue increased $37.3 million (excluding revenue from the Provider Fee Program) from the same period in fiscal year 2015, mainly due to increased reimbursement from commercial managed care payers, and an increase in outpatient visits. Other revenue increased in the period by $12.7 million principally due to the increase in receipts of unrestricted donor funds. Total operating expenses increased approximately $108.7 million, or 8.8% fiscal year over fiscal year (excluding expense related to the Provider Fee Program). Salaries and employee benefits increased by $66.7 million, or 12.9%, from fiscal year 2015 to fiscal year 2016 as LPCH began to increase employee recruitment and training in preparation of the opening of the Expansion. All other expenses (excluding expense from the Provider Fee Program) increased in total by $41.9 million, or 5.9%, principally due to increases in payments to the Stanford School of Medicine for services provided by the physician faculty and higher supply costs resulting from usage of prosthetics, hemophilia factor and surgical supplies. New outpatient facilities openings in Sunnyvale and Los Gatos also contributed to one-time costs in fiscal year 2016. Expense recorded under the Provider Fee Program in fiscal year 2016 was $24.2 million, as compared to $43.2 million in 2015. LPCH’s total assets grew by $286.0 million in fiscal year 2016, or 10.0%, driven by a combination of cash generated from operations, strong investment and fundraising results, and an investment of generated operating funds in property and equipment. Cash and cash equivalents increased in fiscal year 2016 over fiscal year 2015 by 58.6%, or $197.0 million, due to a combination of proceeds from the 2016 Series B Bonds combined with planned withdrawals from the Merged Pool, partially offset by construction expenses related to the Project. Current assets increased $225.9 million, or 34.2%, and current liabilities increased $21.2 million, or 8.7%. Within current assets, net patient account receivables decreased by $3.6 million to $268.2 million, primarily due to improvements in revenue cycle. Net property and equipment increased in fiscal year 2016 by $351.0 million, or 32.6%, as compared to fiscal year 2015, mainly due to the construction of the Project and new outpatient facilities in Sunnyvale and Los Gatos. Net assets increased $157.2 million in fiscal year 2016 over fiscal year 2015. Debt Service Coverage The following table was prepared by management of LPCH and presents historical coverage of maximum annual debt service on all long-term indebtedness of LPCH for the three fiscal years ended August 31, 2014, 2015 and 2016 and pro forma debt service coverage for LPCH for the fiscal year ended August 31, 2016, adjusted to reflect the issuance of the Bonds. Income available for debt service is calculated in accordance with the covenant requirements of the Master Indenture. A-35

�2�� ��� �� �� ����� � �� ����.��� �(� ��� � ��� �� ,���.���� � � ����(8� ��� ��2�� ��� � ����.���� � ��2��� �� �� ���$��2� �� (�� � ���� ��2�� ��� � ���� �� �������� �� � ��� ��(� ��2�� ��� ��� �� �� .��� ��� 3��� � � �� �� � � ������� ��� ���� �� �� ��� ����� �� � ���� = ��� >,� .��� � �?@�� � ���� ,� .��� � �� ��� �� ��2� ������� ����� � �� ����� �� �� 2� �� (� �� ��2�� ��� �8� ��������.� ����� ���� ����� �;��2���� �8�. 2� ���� � ����� � � ����� � ���� � ���8� �;�� (� ���� � ���� ������ ���� �����8� ���� �� � �� ���� ��2�� ��� �� ��� �� �� �����8� �� �.� �� � ��2�� ��� ��� � ������� �� � �� � ��� ��� ,� .��� � �� ��� ��� �� ��� � � �� �� ��� �� �����8� ����� ��.�������� � � � �� �� ��� �� �� ��� �� � �� 8� ��2������� ���� ����<���.����� �� ����� �� ������� � ������������ ���� ���� �2�� ��� ��� ���.��� �������������� ���������� �� �2������ 2� ���������8�������� �����2�� ��� ��� ���.��� �� �� �� ����(�� � � ��(���3���

� �,�(�:&8�)4&18������������� ���� ��(�F&�&7������ �� �������������2�� ��� �8�� ��� ��� 3� ��F&�)&������ ��� ���.�� �:&8�)4&6�����F&�:1������ ��� ���.�� �:&8�)4&/���� �,�(�:&8�)4&18�F::&�A� ����� ��3� �� ����� ���� ����� �;��2���� �� ���� FA/7�1������ ��3� �� ��2�� ��� ��� �� ���.�� � :&8� )4&68� ��� ���� ��(�F/:)�7������ ��3� �����������������;��2���� ��������� ���� ��(�F617�)������ ��3� �� ��2�� ��� ��� �� ���.�� �:&8�)4&/8���� ���� ��(�F::/�7������ ��3� �����������������;��2���� ������ ��� ���� ��(�F&�45������ ��3� ����2�� ��� ���

Liquidity and Capital Resources The following table prepared by management of LPCH sets forth the consolidated cash position and liquidity of LPCH as of the periods set forth below. Liquidity (Dollars in Thousands) As of As of August 31, 2016 May 31, 2017 Cash and Cash Equivalents $ 532,900 $ 331,780 Investments 70,642 87,257 Investments in Stanford University Managed 608,365 772,246 Pools‘? Project Funds — 2014 and 2016 Bonds 219 219 Total Cash, Cash Equivalents and Investments $1,212,126 $1,191,502 Less Temporarily and Permanently Restricted Assets, 2014 and 2016 Bonds Project Funds”) (451,987) (332,163) Total Unrestricted Cash, Cash Equivalents and Investments $ 760,139 $ 859,339 Days Cash on Hand”) 212 222 Consists of LPCH’s share of the Merged Pool described below under the caption “Investments” herein. °) Excludes grant funds and donor restricted funds that have already been spent on the Project but cannot be released from Temporary Restricted Net Assets until the Project is in service. ®) Total liquid assets times the number of days in the period divided by the total operating expenses in the period, net of depreciation and amortization. Source: LPCH records. Investments. Oversight of LPCH’s cash and investment portfolio is provided by the Finance Committee of the Board. Cash is invested to preserve capital through minimizing market and credit risk. Investments of LPCH are managed by the Stanford Management Company, the investment management division of the University. The investment assets of LPCH are primarily invested in a merged endowment pool that combines the assets of multiple entities (the “Merged Pool’). The Merged Pool is a diversified fund comprised of a variety of investments, including cash and cash equivalents, government and corporate debt securities, equity securities and mutual funds, real estate and investments in partnerships, among other investments. LPCH’s interest in the Merged Pool is accounted for on a share basis, reflecting LPCH’s proportionate share of the interest, dividends and realized gains or losses of the securities held in the pool. Investment earnings are included in the excess of revenues over expenses, unless the investment earnings are restricted by donor or by law. At May 31, 2017, LPCH had approximately $1.19 billion of cash and investments, compared with $1.21 billion at August 31, 2016 and $1.37 billion at August 31, 2015. At May 31, 2017, $331.8 million were cash and cash equivalents and $859.7 million were investments. At August 31, 2016, approximately $532.9 million were cash and cash equivalents and approximately $679.2 million were investments. At August 31, 2015, approximately $335.9 million were cash and cash equivalents and approximately $1.04 billion were investments. A-37

�

MMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM� � � ��D����������� ���� �� ���� �������������� � ���� ��� ������������������-� � �������������� � ���� ��

������� ����� (� � .��� � �� ��.������� � ��2�� ��� � ��� ��� ��� �������� � ��� �� .�� ����� �� �� �� �� � � ��� � ��� ���� ��� � �� �� � �� �� � �� ��2�� ��� � � � �� �� � ���� 2����� �� ��� ��2�� ��� � � � �� ��������� �� ���� �� ���� � ��������3����� � ����� ����� �� ����������.� �� ���2����� �� ��� ���� �(��.����� � �����

� �

As of May 31, 2017, approximately $332 million of total investments were held with restrictions imposed by donors. Such restrictions may preclude the use of such assets to pay principal of or interest on the Bonds. In addition, $219 thousand of total investments is comprised of funds on deposit in the project funds for the 2014 and 2016 Bonds. The composition of investments, including the cost when purchased and the fair market value at August 31, 2016, is as follows: Investment Composition (Dollars in Thousands) Cost Fair Market Value Cash and Cash Equivalents $ 532,900 $ 532,900 Investments 467,137 669,793 Board Designated Funds 9,214 9,214 Project Funds - 2014 and 2016 Bonds 219 219 Total $1,009,470 $1,212,126 Source: LPCH audited consolidated financial statements attached as Appendix B to this Official Statement. LPCH’s ability to generate significant investment income is dependent in large measure on market conditions and the composition of its investment portfolio. The value of the investment portfolio has fluctuated from time to time and will continue to fluctuate depending on the value of the underlying securities. A-38

Other Liquidity Contingencies-� � ����� ��� �� �� �(� ������� ���� � � �2 ������ �� � �� �� � ��� � ����.�F7�&������ ��� ���.�� �:&8�)4&68� ��������.�F1�6������ �� �;�� ���������� � (� � � ���3 �� ��� � ������ � ������� ��������������F&�5������ ��� ����� � (�� �� �� �� � �8� �� � � ���������� ������� ���� ����� ��� (������� ������� ��� �8����������� �� �3�� �� ������� � �� ��� ��� �� � ������ � �8���� �� ��� ���� � )48� )4&68������ ��� ������� ���� � �� �� � � �� � ��� � � � F)�/������ �� ��� ��� � �� ��� �� � � � ��;���� � �� �� ���� �.% � ��. ������������ � �� ���������������� 2���� ��� �111�B�����" ��8���� � �� 8����� ��� �� ������ � � ��� ��� ������ ������� �3���� ������������ ��� 2������ ���.�� �� �� ��� F&�4� ����� �� � ��� � � � �� � �� (� � ����� (� ���� �� ��� � � ��� *�� � ��� � �� � � �� �� �� �%�� (� ����� ��

Capitalization The following table sets forth the actual capitalization of LPCH at August 31, 2016 and the capitalization at August 31, 2016, as adjusted to reflect the issuance of the Bonds, as if the issuance had occurred at August 31, 2016, without reflecting any expenses to be incurred or realized by LPCH in connection with such transaction. Capitalization (Dollars in Thousands) August 31, 2016 Actual As Adjusted Long-term Debt: Bonds $ - $ 200,000 2016 Bonds 173,675 173,675 2014 Bonds 200,000 200,000 2012 Bonds 242,195 242,195 Less: Current Maturities (5,695) (5,695) Long-Term Debt $ 610,175 $ 810,175 Net Assets: Unrestricted Net Assets 1,411,433 1,411,433 Restricted Net Assets 785,467 785,467 Total Net Assets $2,196,900 $2,196,900 Total Capitalization $2,807,075 $3,007,075 Net Long-Term Debt as a Percentage of Total Capitalization 21.7% 26.9% Source: LPCH records. Master Indenture Obligations. Under the Master Indenture, LPCH is authorized to issue Obligations pursuant to a Supplemental Master Indenture to evidence or secure indebtedness. Obligations have been issued to secure the 2012 Bonds, the 2014 Bonds, LPCH’s obligations to the purchaser of the 2014 Series B Bonds pursuant to an agreement between LPCH and the purchaser, the 2016 Bonds and a line of credit of $200 million secured by LPCH in May 2017. An Obligation also will be issued to secure the Bonds. Other Liquidity Contingencies. LPCH is directly liable under irrevocable letters of credit totaling $9.1 million at August 31, 2016, including $7.6 million required as security for the workers’ compensation deductible plan and $1.4 million for security for construction, operation and maintenance of certain utility facilities. To date, LPCH has not drawn on these letters of credit. In addition, as of September 20, 2016, LPCH is liable under a letter of credit for $2.5 million related to a deposit for acquisition of the long-term ground lease interest in land and improvements at 777 Welch Road, Palo Alto, and to date this letter of credit has not been drawn upon. LPCH also serves as the guarantor for a $1.0 million loan to South County Community Health Center in East Palo Alto from a third-party lender. A-39

�� 2����*��� (���� � � �� � ����$�� �%$�� ������� ��� ��B �� ��=>�* $%$�B?@� �� ���� �� :17� ���� (���� ��� �� ���� ���� � � �� � ��8� ��������.� � ���������.8� � �� �� 2���8� �� ���.� ����� �� ��

FUNDRAISING Charitable fundraising has historically provided significant financial support to LPCH and fundraising results have continued to be strong. LPFCH is the primary community fundraising agent for LPCH. All contributions raised by LPFCH that are designated for LPCH are reported as revenues of LPCH. In fiscal year 2016, LPFCH raised more than $207 million, of which $142 million was allocated to LPCH. A campaign launched by LPFCH in 1999, Campaign for Lucile Packard Children’s Hospital (the “1999 Campaign’), raised a total of $526 million, of which $385 million was allocated to LPCH. The 1999 Campaign focused on raising funds to support LPCH’s program development, the establishment of six Centers of Excellence, facility expansion and endowment growth, as well as faculty recruitment and pediatric program development at the Stanford School of Medicine. A campaign launched by LPFCH in 2005, Breaking New Ground (the “2005 Campaign’’), raised a total of $262 million for the Project. The 2005 Campaign focused on raising funds to support the Project, to support program development and to endow fellows and faculty scholars in child health programs at the Stanford School of Medicine. In December 2012, LPFCH began the quiet phase of a fundraising campaign with an anticipated goal of at least $750 million (the “New Campaign”). The New Campaign is a comprehensive joint campaign with the Stanford School of Medicine that focuses on raising funds to support completion of the first and fifth floors of the Expansion, to support the Hospital’s programs, to support research and to endow faculty leaders at the Stanford School of Medicine. As of July 15, 2017, the New Campaign has raised over $560 million, of which over $271 million was allocated to LPCH. Together, the 2005 Campaign and the New Campaign have raised a total of $265 million for the construction of the Project, other than the first and fifth floors of the Expansion. As of May 31, 2017, $256 million has been collected in cash. The balance consists of pledges and intentions to give. Intentions to give enable donors to fulfill their commitments through a family foundation or donor-advised fund. OTHER INFORMATION Employees As of May 2017, LPCH had 3,508 FTE employees, including 1,003 FTE registered nurses. The turnover rates for all employees in fiscal years 2016, 2015 and 2014 were 12.4%, 12.2% and 11.2%, respectively. In fiscal year 2016, the turnover rate for registered nurses was 9.1%. The vacancy rate for nurses is currently 11.8%. LPCH currently has collective bargaining agreements with two labor unions which represent 40% of LPCH employees. The Committee for Recognition of Nursing Achievement (“CRONA”) currently represents 1,289 full-time and part-time registered nurses, which represent approximately 31% of LPCH employees. CRONA is a local, non-affiliated nurses’ union. The current contract with CRONA, which commenced in April 2016, is scheduled to expire in March 2019. Service Employees International Union-United Healthcare Workers (“SEIU-UHW’) represents 379 employees in certain support positions, including housekeeping, food service, nursing assistants A-40

Defined Contribution Retirement Plan�� � *��� (� � � � ��� � ��� � ��� �������� � � ��� � �� � � ���� ������� �������� ������ ��� �.�� ���� ������ ��������� ������ � ����*��� (� �� � ��� � ��� � ���� ����� 3����� � �� 2�� ��� ������� ��(� � �� ������ �� ����.� ��� ���� ��(� F)7�4� ����� �� ���� F)1�4������ ��� � ���(�� ����������.�� �:&8�)4&6�����)4&/8� ����� �2��(8�� ������������������ �������� ������ ������������� ���� �� ���� ���� � ���� �� �� �� � � �����������.�������� ����� �������������� ��� ���� ���� �� ���� �������������� � ���� ��� ������������������-� � �������������� � ���� ��

Postretirement Medical Benefit Plan���������� �� �(�� 2��������� ������ ������ 2� �.��� � �� ���� �� � �� ���� (���8� � �.�� ��� ���� ����8� �� �� � � ���� � ��� �� �(� ��� �.�� //8� 3� �� (�� �� �� �� 2����������������(����������� � � ������������� ������ ������ 2� �.��� � � � ����3� �� ������ ��.��6/� ��� ��� ����� ��� �� � � 2����� � �� �2�� ���� (����� � �� ,����� �� ��������� � � � �� ��� � 2����� � � � � ���� 2� ��.��6/��

0 ��� � ���� �� �����.�� �:&8�)4&6������� ������������� (�2���� � ��8�������������������� � �� � ��� (���� ���.� � ���"��)4&5�B�� ��� ��� �� ��� (� ���������,���)441�� E�� � �� ����8�3����� � �������� �� ��� � ��������������(� ���� ��������� � (�������� � � ������3������ ��������(�������� � ����� �� �� ���� � �� ��� �� ������� ������� ���� ��� ��� � �������� � � ��� � �� ���� � � � � ���� � �������������� ��������

��������� �� ������ ������� (� ����.���� ���� ��(�F&6�1������ ������F&A�)������ ��� � ��� (�� �� ��������.�� � :&8� )4&6� ����)4&/8� ����� �2��(8� ��������� ��� ����%���� ����� ��� 2��� ��������� � �� ���� ��� �������� ���� ��� � ����� �� ���� �� ��� ���.� � �� � � � �� ���� (���� ���� � �2� ���(� ������� ���� (����������� ����� ��������� �� � �� ��� ��� � ��������� ������ � ���������8��������)4&6����� �� ������������ ��F&/78444����������� ����� ����� ���� ��(�F&�6������ �� ��� ����� �� � ������ ��� �������������� �������� (��

Defined Benefit Pension Plans�� ��� ������������� (����� ��� 2� ����(���� �� � ��� (� �������������� ������ �������������(��������������������������� ������ ������������� ��� �������� �� (�� �� ���� 2�������� ������� (������ � ��� � ��� �� � ��� � ��� � ���������� �������� ���� �� ����(� �� � �������� �� ����������� � ���� � ��������� �� ��������� �������� ������ ���

���������������2������ ��.���� �3�� ��(������������� �������� ��������� (� �� �������� ���� (���� ����� �2� ���(� ������� ���� (����� �� 3�2� 8������ ��� �;�� ��� � ����� ������� � � ��� ������������������� ���� � ��������� (��������� �2� ���(������������ (����������������F&7/8444� ���� F)A68444� ��� ����� � � ��� ������� (�� �� ������ ��.�� � :&8� )4&6� ���� )4&/8� ����� �2��(8� 3����� �� ���� ��� �� �� � (�� � ����� �� ��������� ��� ��� � ����� ���� (���� ���� � �2� ���(� ������� ���� (�����

���� ������� � ���� ���� �� ���������� (��������� �2� ���(������������ (����� �� 2� ��� �(� ���� �2� ���(����� ��������������� 2� ����(���� <���� �� � ��� (��������������� ������ ��������� -����� ��� �������� ��(�� �� ���� 2�������� ������� (������ ������ � ����� � ��� � ��� � ��������� �� ������ ���� �� ����(��� � �������� �� ����������� � ���� � ��������� �� ��������� �������� ������ ���

and unit secretary job categories, which represent approximately 9% of LPCH employees. The current contract with SEIU-UHW expires on August 26, 2017. Negotiations on a new agreement, which began on June 15, 2017, are ongoing. Retirement Plans LPCH provides retirement benefits through defined benefit and defined contribution retirement plans covering substantially all benefit-eligible employees and employees previously leased from SHC. Defined Contribution Retirement Plan. Employer contributions to the defined contribution retirement plan are based on a percentage of participant annual compensation. Employer contributions to this plan which are vested immediately to participants totaling approximately $29.0 million and $27.0 million for the years ended August 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively, are included in salaries and benefits expense in the consolidated statements of operations and changes in net assets included in the audited consolidated financial statements attached as Appendix B to this Official Statement. Postretirement Medical Benefit Plan. LPCH currently provides health insurance coverage for certain of its employees, through the SHC plan, upon retirement as early as age 55, with years of service as defined by specific criteria. The health insurance coverage for retirees who are under age 65 is the same as that provided to active employees. A Medicare supplement option is provided for retirees over age 65. For purposes of the August 31, 2016 benefit plan liability valuations, LPCH has assumed future mortality according to the RP 2014 White Collar mortality table and MSS 2007 projection table, which are based on the rates published by the Social Security Administration and which are used by LPCH’s outside actuaries to estimate LPCH’s liabilities related to defined contribution and postretirement medical benefit plans. LPCH has recorded a liability totaling approximately $16.7 million and $18.2 million for the years ended August 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively, included in self-insurance reserves on LPCH’s consolidated balance sheets. This represents the obligation for its employees and previously leased employees. LPCH reimburses SHC for costs related to this plan on a periodic basis, and in 2016 has recorded expense of $159,000 and an increase of approximately $1.6 million to net assets to reduce the minimum benefit liability. Defined Benefit Pension Plans. Certain LPCH employees are covered by a noncontributory defined benefit pension plan held by SHC. SHC’s defined benefit pension plan benefits are based on years of service and the employee’s contribution. Contributions to the plans are based on actuarially determined amounts sufficient to meet the benefits to be paid to plan participants. SHC and LPCH have an arrangement whereby SHC assumes the pension liability of the LPCH employees and previously leased employees. However, LPCH is required to reimburse SHC for the annual expense incurred for these employees and previously leased employees. LPCH paid $195,000 and $286,000 in cash for the fiscal years ended August 31, 2016 and 2015, respectively, which represented current year pension expenses related to LPCH employees and previously leased employees. The remainder of certain other LPCH employees and previously leased employees not covered by the previously described plans is covered by a frozen noncontributory defined benefit pension plan. Benefits are based on years of service and the employee’s compensation. Contributions to the plan are based on actuarially determined amounts sufficient to meet the benefits to be paid to plan participants. A-41

0 � ���� ���(�(�� ���� ���� �&8�)4&6� ���� ���� �&8�)4&18��$, ������%���� ���� � ����� � � F&/������ ���� � ������ � ��� ����F)/������ �� ��� ��� � ��� �.. �.� �� � � ��������(�����8��������� ��� � ��� ����� �� ��,�����������$, ������ � ������F&6/������ �� ��������� ����� �����E �� �(�� 2� ��.� ����8� ���� ���� ��� � ��� �� ��� �� �� ,��������� �� ���� � �� � ��� ������� ����� ����8� �$, �� �� ��������� >����� �� ���(?� �� �� 2�����F/������ ���� � ������ � ��� � 2� �.������F&4������ �� ��� � ��� �.. �.� ��������� �� �������%���� ���F&4������ ���� �������� �������F&/������ ������ ����.. �.� �������� � ���(�3 ��� � ������ ��� ����%���� ��� ��(� �3� ���� �$, ��� � 0 � � ���(� (�� �� ��� �� ��� ���� � &8� )44/����� ������ � �� � �� � �� ����� ���&8�)4448��$, ��� 2����� ��� ����%������� 2� �.�� �� ��� ���� ��� ��� � ��� � ��� (� � ��� ��(� � ��� �� �� �� �� 3���� F/������ �� ���� F&/������ �� ���� ���� �� ������� ������� ����� ����� ��� �� �� �� �� 3���� F&44� ����� �� ���� F)44� ����� ��� � �$, �� ���� ��� � �������� � 2� �.��� �� ����� ����������� (� �������� � ��� �������� ��.��� ������ ��� ��� � ����

�$, ������%���� ��� ����� � �F&�)/������ ���� �������� ��(�� � ������� (�� 2� �.�� ���������� �� F&�)/������ ���� ���������$, ���� �������F/4������ �� ��������� ����� �����E �� �(�� 2� ��.�����8� �������� ���� ��� ����� �� ��,����������

�� ���� � �� � � 2� �.�� � 2����� �(� �$, �8������ � ����� � 2� �.�� �� 2� � ��� ����� ���� � � ���������������(�� ��� ��������� � ����������� ������� (������(�������������3���������������8������ ���� 8��������� �.� ��.���� � ������������� ������� ������� 2� �.���2�������� � ��� �� ��� ������ ���� ���3 �� ���� ������ � ��� 2� �.�� E �� �(�3� ���������� �� ��� ������ ������� � ��� �� �� ��� ������� ��������� ����8�3��������F1/48444��� ������8�F)4�/������ ����������.. �.� ��� � ����������(�� � �����.���.�� �:&8�)4&1�� �B �� ���� ������ � ��� 2� �.�� ������� ������ ����� �� ��� ���� �� �3� �� ��� � � � (� �;�� ���� �� �� ��� � � ��� � ����� � ����� � �� (� ����.�� ���� ��������� �� � �� � �� ���� ��������� �� ��� ������ �������3� ������ ����� ���3� ����������������� ��� �� � ��F/44������ �� ��� 2� �.���� � ��� ����8����E�� � �2� � ���������� ��� ����� � � ��� (������ ��������� ������ �� (� � ���(��������� ���� ��� (����� ������ �� �� (�����.�� ������������ � �� � ���� �� �(���������(� ����� �;����I�� 3�2� 8�� �� (�����.�� ������������ � �� � ����������(��� �8����� �� �8��� ����� � �����.�� � �� �� � �� 3��.� ��� �� �;�����3 ���� ��� � 2� ��� �(� ��� F/44������ �� � ���(� ���� � � ���

See “BONDHOLDERS’ RISKS—Significant Risk Areas Summarized—Pension and Benefit Funding” in the forepart of this Official Statement for general information regarding liability of entities in a controlled group for unfunded pension obligations. Accreditation, Licenses and Memberships LPCH is licensed by the California Department of Public Health and is accredited by The Joint Commission. Its most recent three-year accreditation became effective November 2016. LPCH is a member of the Children’s Hospital Association, the California Children’s Hospital Association, the California Hospital Association, the Hospital Council of Northern and Central California, Santa Clara County Division, the National Association of Children’s Hospitals and Related Institutions and the American Hospital Association. Insurance LPCH maintains coverage of professional and comprehensive general liability through programs of self-insurance and reinsurance. Primary and excess layers of such liability are insured through SUMIT, under policies written on a claims made basis. SUMIT provides hospital liability insurance covering general liability, health care professional liability, cyber liability, and miscellaneous errors and omissions to LPCH and SHC (including the clinical activities of the Stanford School of Medicine faculty and residents) on a combined basis. For the policy year September 1, 2016 to September 1, 2017, SUMIT self-insures for the first $15 million per claim loss and $25 million in the loss aggregate for claims by LPCH, SHC and the Stanford School of Medicine. SUMIT has obtained $165 million of excess reinsurance jointly covering LPCH, SHC and the Stanford School of Medicine. In addition to the excess reinsurance, SUMIT purchases a “buffer policy” that provides $5 million per claim loss coverage and $10 million in loss aggregate excess of the self-insured $10 million per claim loss and $15 million in loss aggregate. This policy works to reduce the self-insured layer within SUMIT. For policy years before September 1, 2005 and since its creation in April 1, 2000, SUMIT provides occurrence-based coverage of the risk related to the primary loss layer in amounts between $5 million and $15 million and has purchased excess reinsurance in amounts between $100 million and $200 million. SUMIT has also assumed coverage for professional liability of LPCH for occurrences during certain earlier periods. SUMIT self-insures the first $1.25 million per claim for cyber liability coverage in excess of $1.25 million per claim. SUMIT purchases $50 million of excess reinsurance jointly covering LPCH, SHC and the Stanford School of Medicine. In addition to coverage provided by SUMIT, LPCH obtains coverage of various risks under policies issued by commercial insurers. These policies typically name SHC as well as LPCH and, as a result, claims brought against one named insured can reduce coverage available to the others. LPCH secures workers’ compensation coverage jointly with SHC under commercial policies for amounts in excess of a deductible, which is $750,000 per claim, $20.5 million annual aggregate for the fiscal year ending August 31, 2017. Workers’ compensation coverage is maintained in amounts consistent with the statutory requirements of the State. LPCH obtains property damage and business interruption insurance under commercial policies with limits shared with SHC in a blanket amount of $500 million of coverage per occurrence, subject to various exclusions or limitations typical of an all risks property policy. LPCH does not carry insurance for property damage or business interruption directly caused by an earthquake; however, property damage or business interruption caused by fire, explosion, sprinkler leakage or flood following an earthquake would be covered by the $500 million policy limit noted A-42

�

�� 2����� �� (�����.�� ������������ � �� � ����������(����� ��� �� 3��.������ �;�����3 ������� ���E�� � ���F/4������ ����������.. �.� ��������� �������� � ������� �� ������� ����� ���������� (����� ���� (��� �� �� ����� ������� (� � 2� �.������ � � ��� ����� � �������3� ��FA4������ �� �� ���� �� ��� ��� 3� �� ���8� ���E�� � � ����� ������ �� F)/48444� �� � ������ � � �� �� ��� ���� ����� ��� ������� (� ���� F/448444� �� � ������ � � ���� (��� � � �� ����� ������� (� ��� ��� ������� (�� � �����.� ��.�� � :&8� )4&1��� ����8� E �� �(�3� �����8��� �������F)/������ �� �� � ���� ������� (�� 2� �.�����E�� � ���F/448444� ����%���� ��� � �� � ��� � ����� ��� � �� ������� ������� (� ������� (8� � ���8� �2�� � �8� ���� �� � ���� ����� � ��������

above. Property damage or business interruption caused by a flood following an earthquake would be subject to a $50 million annual aggregate sublimit. LPCH obtains directors’ and officers’ liability and employment practices liability coverage under commercial policies with $80 million of limits shared with SHC, subject to deductibles of $250,000 per claim for directors’ and officers’ liability and $500,000 per claim for employment practices liability in the fiscal year ending August 31, 2017. LPCH, jointly with SHC, purchases $25 million of terrorism liability coverage subject to a $500,000 self-insured retention. LPCH also purchases fiduciary liability, crime, aviation, and auto insurance policies. A-43
